113
         Rules of construction for offenses and penalties - see GEN. OFF. 
501.04
         Statute of limitations on prosecutions - see GEN. OFF.
501.06
   101.01  DESIGNATION; CITATION; HEADINGS.
   (a)    All ordinances of a permanent and general nature of the Municipality
as revised, codified, rearranged, renumbered and consolidated into component
codes, titles, chapters and sections shall be known and designated as the
Codified Ordinances of Twinsburg, Ohio, 1979, for which designation "Codified
Ordinances" may be substituted. Code, title, chapter and section headings do
not constitute any part of the law as contained in the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.01)
   (b)    All references to codes, titles, chapters and sections are to such
components of the Codified Ordinances unless otherwise specified. Any component
code may be referred to and cited by its name, such as the "Traffic Code".
Sections may be referred to and cited by the designation "Section" followed by
the number, such as "Section
101.01".
   101.02  GENERAL DEFINITIONS.
   As used in the Codified Ordinances, unless another definition is provided or
the context otherwise requires:
   (a)    "And" may be read "or", and "or" may be read "and", if the sense
requires it.
(ORC 1.02 (F))
   (b)    "Another" when used to designate the owner of property which is the
subject of an offense, includes not only natural persons but also every other
owner of property.
(ORC 1.02 (B))
   (c)    "Bond" includes an undertaking and "undertaking" includes a bond.
      (ORC 1.02 (D), (E))
   (d)    "Council" means the legislative authority of the Municipality.
   (e)    "County" means Summit County, Ohio.
   (f)    "Keeper" or "proprietor" includes all persons, whether acting by
themselves or as a servant, agent or employee.
   (g)    “Land” or "real estate" includes rights and easements of an
incorporeal nature.
(ORC 701.01 (F))
   (h)    "Municipality" or "City" means the City of Twinsburg, Ohio.
   (i)    "Oath" includes affirmation and "swear" includes affirm.
(ORC 1.59(B))
   (j)    "Owner", when applied to property, includes any part owner, joint
owner or tenant in common of the whole or part of such property.
   (k)    "Person" includes an individual, corporation, business trust, estate,
trust, partnership and association.
(ORC 1.59 (C))
   (l)    "Premises", as applied to property, includes land and buildings.
   (m)    "Property" means real and personal property.
(ORC 1.59(E))
      "Personal property" includes all property except real.
      "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
   (n)    "Public authority" includes boards of education; the Municipal,
County, State or Federal government, its officers or an agency thereof; or any
duly authorized public official.
   (o)    "Public place" includes any street, sidewalk, park, cemetery, school
yard, body of water or watercourse, public conveyance, or any other place for
the sale of merchandise, public accommodation or amusement.
   (p)    "Registered mail" includes certified mail and "certified mail"
includes registered mail.
(ORC 1.02 (G))
   (q)    "Rule " includes regulation.
(ORC 1.59 (F))
   (r)    "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb line and
the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians.
   (s)    "This State" or "the State" means the State of Ohio.
(ORC 1.59(G))
   (t)    "Street" includes alleys, avenues, boulevards, lanes, roads,
highways, viaducts and all other public thoroughfares within the Municipality.
   (u)    "Tenant" or "occupant", as applied to premises, includes any person
holding a written or oral lease, or who actually occupies the whole or any part
of such premises, alone or with others.
   (v)    "Whoever" includes all persons, natural and artificial; partners;
principals, agents and employees; and all officials, public or private.
(ORC 1.02(A))
   (w)    "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words,
letters, symbols or figures. This provision does not affect any law relating to
signatures.
      (ORC 1.59(J))
   101.03  RULES OF CONSTRUCTION.
   (a)    Common and Technical Usage. Words and phrases shall be read in
context and construed according to the rules of grammar and common usage. Words
and phrases that have acquired a technical or particular meaning, whether by
legislative definition or otherwise, shall be construed accordingly.
(ORC 1.42)
   (b)    Singular and Plural; Gender; Tense. As used in the Codified
Ordinances, unless the context otherwise requires:
      (1)    The singular includes the plural, and the plural includes the
singular.
      (2)    Words of one gender include the other genders.
      (3)    Words in the present tense include the future.
(ORC 1.43)
   (c)   Calendar; Computation of Time.
      (1)    Definitions.
         A.    "Week" means seven consecutive days.
         B.    "Year" means twelve consecutive months.
            (ORC 1.44)
      (2)    If a number of months is to be computed by counting the months
from a particular day, the period ends on the same numerical day in the
concluding month as the day of the month from which the computation is begun,
unless there are not that many days in the concluding month, in which case the
period ends on the last day of that month.
(ORC 1.45)
      (3)    The time within which an act is required by law to be done shall
be computed by excluding the first and including the last day, except that when
the last day falls on Sunday or a legal holiday, then the act may be done on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday. When a public
office, in which an act required by law is to be performed, is closed to the
public for the entire day which constitutes the last day for doing such act or
before its usual closing time on such day, then such act may be performed on
the next succeeding day which is not a Sunday or a legal holiday. If any legal
holiday falls on Sunday, the next succeeding day is a legal holiday.
(ORC 1.14)
      (4)    When legislation is to take effect or become operative from and
after a day named, no part of that day shall be included.
(ORC 1.15)
      (5)    In all cases where the law shall require any act to be done in a
reasonable time or reasonable notice to be given, such reasonable time or
notice shall mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance
of such duty or compliance with such notice.
   (d)    Authority. When the law requires an act to be done which may by law
as well be done by an agent as by the principal, such requirement shall be
construed to include all such acts when done by an authorized agent.
   (e)    Joint Authority. All words purporting to give joint authority to
three or more municipal officers or other persons shall be construed as giving
such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons, unless it shall
be otherwise expressly declared in the law giving the authority or inconsistent
with State statute or Charter provisions.
   (f)    Exceptions. The rules of construction shall not apply to any law
which shall contain any express provision excluding such construction, or when
the subject matter or context of such law may be repugnant thereto.
   101.04  REVIVOR; EFFECT OF AMENDMENT OR REPEAL.
   (a)    The repeal of a repealing ordinance does not revive the ordinance
originally repealed nor impair the effect of any saving clause therein.
(ORC 1.57)
   (b)    An ordinance which is re-enacted or amended is intended to be a
continuation of the prior ordinance and not a new enactment, so far as it is
the same as the prior ordinance.
(ORC 1.54)
   (c)    The re-enactment, amendment or repeal of an ordinance does not,
except as provided in subsection (d) hereof:
      (1)    Affect the prior operation of the ordinance or any prior action
taken thereunder;
      (2)    Affect any validation, cure, right, privilege, obligation or
liability previously acquired, accrued, accorded or incurred thereunder;
      (3)    Affect any violation thereof or penalty, forfeiture or punishment
incurred in respect thereto, prior to the amendment or repeal;
      (4)    Affect any investigation, proceeding or remedy in respect of any
such privilege, obligation, liability, penalty, forfeiture or punishment; and
the investigation, proceeding or remedy may be instituted, continued or
enforced, and the penalty, forfeiture or punishment imposed, as if the
ordinance had not been repealed or amended.
   (d)    If the penalty, forfeiture or punishment for any offense is reduced
by a re- enactment or amendment of an ordinance, the penalty, forfeiture or
punishment, if not already imposed, shall be imposed according to the ordinance
as amended.
(ORC 1.58)
   101.05  CONSTRUCTION OF SECTION REFERENCES.
   (a)    A reference to any portion of the Codified Ordinances applies to all
reenactments or amendments thereof.
(ORC 1.55)
   (b)    If a section refers to a series of numbers or letters, the first and
the last numbers or letters are included.
(ORC 1.56)
   (c)    Wherever in a penalty section reference is made to a violation of a
series of sections or of subsections of a section, such reference shall be
construed to mean a violation of any section or subsection included in such
reference.
   References in the Codified Ordinances to action taken or authorized under
designated sections of the Codified Ordinances include, in every case, action
taken or authorized under the applicable legislative provision which is
superseded by the Codified Ordinances.
(ORC 1.23)
   101.06  CONFLICTING PROVISIONS.
   (a)    If there is a conflict between figures and words in expressing a
number, the words govern.
(ORC 1.46)
   (b)    If a general provision conflicts with a special or local provision,
they shall be construed, if possible, so that effect is given to both. If the
conflict between the provisions is irreconcilable, the special or local
provision prevails as an exception to the general provision, unless the general
provision is the later adoption and the manifest intent is that the general
provision prevail.
(ORC 1.51)
   (c)    (1)    If ordinances enacted at different meetings of Council are
irreconcilable, the ordinance latest in date of enactment prevails.
      (2)    If amendments to the same ordinance are enacted at different
meetings of Council, one amendment without reference to another, the amendments
are to be harmonized, if possible, so that effect may be given to each. If the
amendments are substantively irreconcilable, the latest in date of enactment
prevails. The fact that a later amendment restates language deleted by an
earlier amendment, or fails to include language inserted by an earlier
amendment, does not of itself make the amendments irreconcilable. Amendments
are irreconcilable only when changes made by each cannot reasonably be put into
simultaneous operation.
         (ORC 1.52)
   101.07  DETERMINATION OF LEGISLATIVE INTENT.
   (a)    In enacting an ordinance, it is presumed that:
      (1)    Compliance with the constitutions of the State and of the United
States is intended;
      (2)    The entire ordinance is intended to be effective;
      (3)    A just and reasonable result is intended;
      (4)    A result feasible of execution is intended.
(ORC 1.47)
   (b)    An ordinance is presumed to be prospective in its operation unless
expressly made retrospective.
(ORC 1.48)
   (c)    If an ordinance is ambiguous, the court, in determining the intention
of Council may consider among other matters:
      (1)    The object sought to be attained;
      (2)    The circumstances under which the ordinance was enacted;
      (3)    The legislative history; 
      (4)    The common law or former legislative provisions, including laws
upon the same or similar subjects;
      (5)    The consequences of a particular construction;
      (6)    The administrative construction of the ordinance.
(ORC 1.49)
   101.08  SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of a section of the Codified Ordinances or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, the invalidity does not
affect the other provisions or applications of the section or related sections
which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to
this end the provisions are severable.
(ORC 1.50)
   101.99  GENERAL PENALTY.
   Whenever, in the Codified Ordinances or in any ordinance of the
Municipality, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an
offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever the doing of any act is required or the
failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where no specific penalty is
otherwise provided, whoever violates any such provision shall be punished by a
fine not exceeding one hundred dollars ($100.00). A separate offense shall be
deemed committed each day during or on which a violation continues or occurs.

Official Standards
103.01   Seal.
103.02   Flag.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Custody and use of seal - see CHTR. §
3.11(f)
         State standard of time - see Ohio R.C. 1.04
         State legal holidays - see Ohio R.C. 1.14, 5.20 et seq.
   103.01  SEAL.
   (a)    The Seal of the Clerk of the Municipality shall be one and three-
fourths inches in diameter and shall be surrounded by the words "City of
Twinsburg, Twinsburg, Ohio".
   (b)    The seal of the Clerk is designated as the seal of the Municipality.
An impression of the seal shall be affixed to all transcripts, orders,
certificates and all other documents requiring authentication.

official flag of the City.

CHAPTER 107
Meetings of Municipal Bodies
107.01   Definitions.
107.02   Secretaries' notice to Clerk.
107.03   Clerk's notice to the public at large.
107.04   Clerk's notice to the news media.
107.05   Executive sessions.
107.06   Recording of minutes; publication.
107.07   General provisions; notice.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Authority to establish - see CHTR. §
7.01
         Open meetings (Sunshine law) - see Ohio R.C. 121.22
         Council meetings - see ADM.
111.02
   107.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Agenda" means a listing of the subject or subjects to be discussed at
a meeting which is as complete as practicable at the time of making such
agenda. This does not preclude additional items from appearing upon any agenda
which have not been anticipated and which have arisen between the preparation
of the agenda and the time of the meeting and which are of an urgent or
reasonably important nature to be resolved. A good-faith attempt to prepare a
predetermined agenda shall be all that is required hereinunder.
   (b)    "Clerk" means the Clerk of City Council.
   (c)    "Day" means calendar day.
   (d)    "Executive session" means a regular or special meeting of any
municipal body and any and all subcommittees thereof which is called for
consideration of special matters as more fully set forth in Section
107.05 hereof.
   (e)    "Meeting" means any prearranged discussion of the public business of
a municipal body by a majority of the members of the municipal body. This term
shall further include "work sessions".
   (f)   "Municipal body" means each of the following and any and all
subcommittees thereof and any City board or commission which might be
established subsequent to this enactment:
      (1)    Assessment Equalization Boards
      (2)    Board of Building and Zoning Code Appeals
      (3)    Board of Review (Income Tax) for nonconfidential matters
      (4)    Architectural Review Board
      (5)    Charter Review Commission
      (6)    Citizens Advisory Commission on Energy
      (7)    City Council
      (8)    Civil Service Commission
      (9)    Finance Committee
      (10)    Land Development Committee
      (11)    Municipal Awards Board
      (12)    Parks and Recreation Commission
      (13)    Parks and Recreation Committee of Council
      (14)    Planning Commission
      (15)    Public Works Committee
      (16)    Safety Committee
      (17)    Volunteer Firemen's Dependents' Fund Board
   (g)    "Oral notification" means notification given orally either in person
or by telephone, directly to the person for whom such notification is intended
or by leaving an oral message for such person at the telephone number of such
person as shown on the records kept by the Clerk as prescribed in this chapter.
   (h)    "Post" means to post in the office of the Clerk during usual business
hours and at the Twinsburg Public Library. A notice identifying the locations
at which notifications will be posted pursuant to this chapter shall be
published by the Clerk within ten calendar days after the enactment hereof.
   (i)    "Published" means published once in a newspaper having a general
circulation in the Municipality as defined by Ohio R.C. 7.12, except that no
portion of such newspaper need be printed in the Municipality.
   (j)    "Secretary" means any and all secretaries or clerks of municipal
bodies other than Council.
   (k)    "Special meeting" means a meeting which is neither a regular meeting
nor an organizational meeting nor a recessed regular or organizational meeting
changed to another time or day.
   (l)    "Written notification" means notification in writing mailed to the
address of the person for whom such notification is intended as shown on the
records kept by the Clerk, as prescribed in this chapter, which shall be mailed
by first class mail not later than forty-eight hours preceding the day of the
meeting, provided that at least one regular mail delivery day falls between the
day of mailing and the day of such meeting.
      (Ord. 59-1976. Passed 6-29-76; Ord. 23-1987. Passed 3-24-87.)
   107.02  SECRETARIES' NOTICE TO CLERK.
   (a)    Meetings of Municipal Bodies. Each secretary shall:
      (1)    File with the Clerk a statement of the time and place of each
respective municipal body's organizational meeting not later than three days
prior to the day of such organizational meeting each year.
      (2)    File with the Clerk a statement of times and places of the regular
meetings of each respective municipal body for each calendar year not later
than three days prior to the day of the first regular meeting each year.
      (3)    File with the Clerk a statement of time and place of any special
meeting of each respective municipal body not later than three days prior to
the day of each such special meeting.
      (4)    File with the Clerk a statement of the time and place of any
recessed meeting not later than twenty-four hours following such recess.
      (5)    Maintain an accurate record of the dates and times such statements
are filed with the Clerk as required by this section.
   (b)    Meeting Agendas of Municipal Bodies. Each secretary shall:
      (1)    File with the Clerk an agenda of specific items planned for
discussion by each respective municipal body not later than three days prior to
the day of such meeting.
      (2)    File with the Clerk an agenda of specific items planned for
discussion at any recessed meeting not later than twenty-four hours following
such recess.
      (3)    Maintain an accurate record of the dates and times such agendas
are filed with the Clerk as required by this section.
         (Ord. 59-1976. Passed 6-29-76.)
   107.03  CLERK'S NOTICE TO THE PUBLIC AT LARGE.
   (a)    Meetings of Municipal Bodies. The Clerk shall:
      (1)    Post a notice of the times and places of each municipal body's
organizational meeting not later than forty-eight hours prior to the time of
each organizational meeting.
      (2)    Post a notice of the times and places of regular meetings of each
municipal body for each calendar year not later than forty-eight hours prior to
the time of the first regular meeting of each municipal body.
      (3)    Post a notice of the times and places of any special meeting of a
municipal body not later than twenty-four hours prior to the time of such
special meeting.
      (4)    Post a notice of the time and place of any recessed meeting not
later than thirty-six hours following such recess.
      (5)    Maintain an accurate record of the dates and times such notices
are posted as required by this chapter.
   (b)    Meeting Agendas of Municipal Bodies. The Clerk shall: maintain a
timely and accurate file of current agendas of all meetings in order to comply
with Sections
107.03(c) and
107.04 hereof.
   (c)    Public Requests for Personal Notice.
      (1)    Any person, upon written request and as provided herein, may
obtain reasonable advance notification of all meetings at which any specific
type of public business is scheduled to be discussed.
      (2)    Such person may file a written request with the Clerk specifying
the person's name, address and telephone number; the specific type of public
business the discussion of which the person is requesting advance notification;
the municipal body that is the subject of such request; and the number of
calendar months which the request covers. Such request may be cancelled by
written request from such person to the Clerk.
      (3)    Each written request must be accompanied by cash or a check or
money order payable to the City. Fees will be charged in accordance with
Chapter
149.
(Ord. 59-1976. Passed 6-29-76.)
   107.04  CLERK'S NOTICE TO THE NEWS MEDIA.
   (a)    Notice of Special Meetings.
      (1)    Any news medium organization that desires to be given advance
notification of special meetings of a municipal body shall file a written
request with the Clerk.
      (2)    Except in the event of an emergency requiring immediate official
action as referred to in subsection (a)(6) hereof, a special meeting shall not
be held unless at least twenty-four hours advance notice of the time, place and
purpose of such special meeting is given to the news media that have requested
such advance notice in accordance with subsection (a)(3) hereof.
      (3)    News media requests for such advance notification of special
meetings shall specify: the municipal body that is the subject of such request;
the name of the medium; and the name and address and telephone numbers at which
notification may be given either during or outside of business hours to such
requesting medium.
      (4)    Any such request shall be effective for one year from the date of
filing with the Clerk or until the Clerk receives written notice from such
medium cancelling or modifying such request, whichever is earlier.
      (5)    The Clerk shall give such oral notification or written
notification, or both, as the Clerk determines, to the news media that have
requested such advance notification in accordance with subsection (a)(3) hereof
of the time, place and purposes of each special meeting at least twenty-four
hours prior to the time of such meeting.
      (6)    In the event an emergency requiring immediate official action, a
special meeting may be held without giving twenty-four hours advance
notification thereof to the requesting news media.
      (7)    Any person calling such meeting shall immediately notify the Clerk
of the date, time and subject or subjects to be discussed.
      (8)    The Clerk shall then give immediate oral notification of such
special meeting and the nature of the emergency requiring immediate official
action to such news media that have requested such advance notification in
accordance with subsection (a)(3) hereof.
      (9)    The Clerk shall maintain an accurate record of the dates and times
such oral or written notification is given as required by this section.
         (Ord. 59-1976.  Passed 6-29-76.)
   107.05  EXECUTIVE SESSIONS.
   The members of a municipal body may hold an executive session only at a
regular or special meeting for the sole purpose of the consideration of the
following matters:
   (a)    To consider the appointment, employment, dismissal, discipline,
promotion, demotion or compensation of a public employee or official or the
investigation of charges or complaints against a public employee, official,
licensee or regulated individual unless the public employee, official, licensee
or regulated individual requests a public hearing;
   (b)    To consider the purchase of property for public purposes or for the
sale of property at competitive bidding, if premature disclosure of information
would give an unfair competitive or bargaining advantage to a person whose
personal, private interest is adverse to the general public interest;
   (c)    Conferences with an attorney for the municipal body concerning
disputes involving the municipal body that is the subject of pending or
imminent court action;
   (d)    Preparing for, conducting or reviewing negotiations or bargaining
sessions with public employees concerning their compensation or other terms and
conditions of their employment;
   (e)    Matters required to be kept confidential by federal law or rules or
State statutes; or
   (f)    Specialized details of security arrangements where disclosure of the
matters discussed might reveal information that could be used for the purpose
of committing or avoiding prosecution for a violation of the law.
      (Ord. 59-1976. Passed 6-29-76.)
   107.06  RECORDING OF MINUTES; PUBLICATION.
   (a)    Each secretary of each respective municipal body and one Clerk, if
the meeting is established by one or more members of Council, shall promptly
record the minutes of each regular or special meeting of the respective
municipal body and open such minutes to public inspection.
   (b)    If, in the event the secretary or the Clerk is unable to attend any
such regular ar special meeting for the purpose of recording such minutes, the
minutes shall be recorded and published by another person designated by the
secretary or the Clerk for such purpose.
   (c)    If, in the event the meeting is considered to be a regular or special
"executive session" held in compliance with Ohio R.C. 121.22 and as more
explicitly set forth in Section
107.05 hereof, the person calling such meeting shall insure the publication of
the minutes of such executive session which shall reflect the general subject
matter discussed at such meeting.
(Ord. 59-1976. Passed 6-29-76.)
   107.07  GENERAL PROVISIONS; NOTICE.
   (a)    Any person may visit or telephone the office of the Clerk during
regular office hours to determine, based on information available in that
office, the time and place of regular meetings; the time, place and purpose of
any then known special meetings; and whether the available agenda of any such
future meeting states that any specific type of public business is to be
discussed at such meeting.
   (b)    Any notification to be given by the Clerk, as provided in this
chapter, may be given by any person acting on behalf of or under the authority
of the Clerk.
(Ord. 59-1976. Passed 6-29-76.)

Council

   111.01  RULES OF COUNCIL.
   (a)   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of Council shall be held as
provided by Charter on the second and fourth Tuesdays of each month in Council
Chambers or at such other location determined and publicized by Council.  Such
meeting shall commence promptly at 7:30 p.m.
   (b)   Special Meetings: The Mayor or any three (3) members of Council may
convene a special meeting of Council in accordance with
 3.07(B) of the Charter.
(Ord. 114-2010.  Passed 10-12-10.)
   111.02  TIME OF MEETINGS.
   (a)   Agenda:   The Mayor and President of Council shall direct the
preparation of the agenda of matters to be brought before Council.  The agenda
shall be delivered to members of Council at least one business day before each
meeting.  However, Council may, by majority vote, suspend this requirement to
consider legislation presented to Council after preparation of the agenda.
   (b)   Order of Business:  At all regular meetings of Council, the business
of Council shall be taken up in the following order:
      (1)   Roll Call
      (2)   Invocation &  Pledge of Allegiance
      (3)   Approval of Minutes
      (4)   Recognitions & Awards
      (5)   Audience Participation
      (6)   Council Communication & Committee Reports [List Committees]
      (7)   Mayors Report
      (8)   Dept. Head Reports
      (9)   Legislation
      (10)   Unfinished Business
      (11)   New Business
      (12)   Miscellaneous
      (13)   Excuse Absent Members
      (14)   Adjournment
      (15)   Unfinished business
      (16)   New business; and
      (17)   Miscellaneous shall be combined on the agenda unless otherwise
determined by the President of Council.
         (Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.03  COMMITTEES.
   (a)   Appointment:  At the first regular or special meeting of each year,
the Council President shall appoint the standing committee members.
   (b)   Standing Committees:  The standing committees of Council shall be: 
      (1)   The Committee of the Whole;
      (2)   Finance Committee;
      (3)   Public Works Committee;
      (4)   Parks and Recreation Committee;
      (5)   Public Safety Committee;
      (6)   Planning Committee;
      (7)   Community Relations Committee.  (Charter 111.01(0))
   (c)   Special Committees:  Special committees of Council shall be appointed
by the Council President or as Council may otherwise designate.  (Charter
111.01(n))
   The President of Council shall be the presiding officer of the Committee of
the
Whole.
   The rules of proceedings of all committees shall be informal, but shall
always be under the control and direction of the President of Council.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.04  DISPOSAL OF SUBJECT MATTER.
   (a)   Procedure:  When a subject is referred to a Committee, the chairperson
of the committee shall schedule a meeting and determine the order of discussion
concerning the subject.
   (b)   Report:  Any matter referred to a committee shall be reported upon by
such committee.  The chairperson shall be responsible for the preparation of
the report.  Any minority of a committee shall have the right to submit a
separate report.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.05  COUNCIL REPRESENTATIVES.
   At the first meeting in December and as necessary thereafter, the President
of Council shall appoint members of Council to serve as representatives of
Council and/or liaisons of boards, commissions and other groups as required by
Charter, ordinance or other law.  Members so appointed shall report to Council
as required. 
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.06  QUORUM.
   Four members of Council shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of
business, but a lesser number may adjourn.  (Charter 111.01(d))
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.07  ROLL CALL.
   The Clerk of Council shall call the roll of members and the names of those
present shall be entered upon the minutes.  Any member unable to attend shall
notify the Clerk of Council prior to the meeting.  A Councilmember shall ask
permission of the chair to leave the meeting for any reason.  (Charter 111.01
(c))
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.08  READING OF MINUTES.
   The proceedings of all meetings shall be taken down by the Clerk of Council
or a secretary appointed for the purpose in accordance with the provisions of
applicable law.  Unless a reading of the minutes of a previous meeting is
requested by a member, such minutes may be approved without reading if the
Clerk of Council has furnished each member with a synopsis thereof.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.09  ORDINANCES AND RESOLUTIONS.
   (a)   Suspension of Rules.  Legislative measures of a general or permanent
nature shall not be adopted until such measures are read by title on three
different days.  Measures required by ordinance, law or Charter to be read on
three different days shall also be so read.  Council, upon the concurrence of
five members, may suspend this rule, declare an emergency and cause any measure
designated as an emergency measure to be read by title only for one reading
only.  No suspension of this rule shall be permitted when such suspension
conflicts with any ordinance or Charter provision.
   (b)   Designation of Emergency Measure.  All emergency legislation before
Council shall contain the following language:  “This ordinance is hereby
declared to be an emergency measure necessary for the preservation of the
public peace, heath, safety, convenience and welfare of the city of Twinsburg
and the inhabitants thereof, for the reason that it is necessary for the
general public heath and welfare and for the reason that ______(stated
reason)______ and provided it receives the affirmative vote of five members of
Council, it shall take effect and be in force immediately upon passage and
approval by the Mayor; otherwise it shall take effect and be in force from and
after the earliest period allowed by law”.
   (c)   Enactment.   Legislation receiving less than five votes after
suspension of the rules, but receiving an affirmative majority and approval of
the Mayor, shall
   (d)   Be considered enacted, but shall be effective only after the
expiration of thirty days from the date of approval by the Mayor.
   (e)   Tie Votes and Negative Votes.  A tie vote or negative majority vote
shall defeat a motion or measure.  Tie votes or negative votes on subsidiary,
incidental or privileged motions shall defeat such motions but shall not
dispose of the ultimate issue.
   (f)   Consent of Council.  Business of a non-legislative nature may be acted
upon by the general or unanimous consent of Council.
   (g)   Rotation of Roll.  The Clerk of Council shall rotate the calling of
the roll among the various members.  (Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.10  MOTIONS.
   (a)   Motions in Order.  When a question or proposition is under
consideration, no motions shall be made except the following:
      (1)   To set a time or place to which to adjourn;
      (2)   To adjourn (not debatable);
      (3)   To table the motion or measure (not debatable);
      (4)   To call for the question (not debatable);
      (5)   To postpone action to a designated future time;
      (6)   To refer to committee;
      (7)   To amend the main motion;
      (8)   To postpone action for an indefinite time.
   (b)   Motion to Amend.  A motion to amend, if duly seconded, is in order; an
amendment to an amendment is in order, but an amendment to an amendment of an
amendment is not in order.
   (c)   Motion to Reconsider.  A motion to reconsider may be made by a member
of the prevailing side only.  A motion to reconsider a subject which was acted
upon favorably must be made at the meeting at which such action was taken.  A
motion to reconsider any other subject must be made no later than the next
regular meeting after such action was taken.  No motion to reconsider shall be
considered more than once on any subject.
   (d)   Motion to Take from the Table.  A motion to take from the table is in
order when that order of business is being transacted during which the question
or measure was laid on the table, or during new business of miscellaneous.
   (e)   Motion to Postpone Indefinitely.  A motion to postpone indefinitely,
if adopted, defeats the question or measure.
   (f)   Motion to Refer to Committee.  A motion to refer to committee is in
order at any time.  Any matter referred remains on the agenda.
   (g)   Motions on Questions of Privilege.  Questions of privilege shall be;
      (1)   Those affecting the rights of Council collectively, its safety,
dignity and the integrity of its proceedings, and
      (2)   The rights, reputation and conduct of members of Council
individually.
   Any motion on a question of privilege has precedence over any motion except
a motion to adjourn.  (Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.11  CONDUCT OF COUNCIL.
   Any Member wishing to gain the floor shall first be recognized by the
President of Council.  No member shall address the same subject more than twice
during the same meeting; no longer than five minutes without leave; nor shall
any member speak more than once on a given motion until every member desiring
to speak shall have had the opportunity to do so.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.12  AUDIENCE PARTICIPATION; REGULAR COUNCIL MEETING.
   (a)   Upon arrival, the person who wishes to address Council must sign in
and state topic with the Clerk of Council.
   (b)   Person will be given the opportunity to speak in the order of signing
in.
   (c)   No more than 3 persons to speak on one specific issue, if other issues
are listed on the sign in sheet.
   (d)   Persons will speak on issue that they state on sign on sheet.
   (e)   Persons granted the floor shall address their remarks to the President
of Council and shall not engage Council members or other officers of the City
to debate.
   (f)   Tirades are not permitted; nor shall any person utter any profane,
derogatory, contemptuous, slanderous, harassing, mean spirited, malicious or
false comment or remarks.
   (g)   The presiding office shall limit to five minutes the time permitted
any speaker to address Council.
   (h)   No person shall address Council more than once at the same meeting.
   (i)   Members of Council may respond during Audience Participation only by
the leave of the President of Council.
   (j)   Audience Participation will not exceed one half hour.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.13  COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE.
   Participation will be in accordance with Section
111.12.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.14  EXECUTIVE SESSION.
   Executive sessions of Council shall be permitted in accordance with the laws
of the State of Ohio and the Charter and ordinances of the City of Twinsburg. 
Such sessions shall be presided over by the Council President and in accordance
with these rules where applicable.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.15  AMENDMENTS OR ADDITIONS TO RULES OF COUNCIL.
   These rules may be amended or additional rules may be adopted by majority
vote of those elected or appointed to Council.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.16  ROBERT'S RULES.
   Except as otherwise provided herein, the deliberations of Council shall be
governed by Robert’s Rules of Order, as revised.
(Ord. 36-2009.  Passed 1-27-09.)
   111.17  SPECIAL COUNSEL.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance 42-2004 was vetoed by the Mayor.)
   111.18  UTILIZATION OF THE AUDIO/VIDEO EQUIPMENT IN COUNCIL CHAMBERS.
   (a)   The audio/visual recording system installed in Council Chambers of
Twinsburg City Hall shall be activated and utilized to record all meetings of
Municipal Bodies as the same are defined in Chapter
107 of the Codified Ordinances of the City of Twinsburg.
   (b)   The administration of the City of Twinsburg may utilize said system to
record such additional meetings and events as it deems appropriate consistent
with the purpose of this section and the laws of the State of Ohio and City of
Twinsburg.
   (c)   Council may, by motion, utilize said system to record such additional
meetings and events as it deems appropriate consistent with the purpose of this
section and the laws of the State of Ohio and City of Twinsburg.
   (d)   Exceptions to the standards and procedures established herein may be
authorized by a majority of Council for good cause shown and in accordance with
the laws of the State of Ohio and City of Twinsburg as they pertain to public
meetings and open records.
(Ord. 86-2004.  Passed 6-8-04.)
   111.19  DONATIONS FOR CHARITABLE CAUSES PROHIBITED.
   (a)   Council is hereby prohibited from authorizing the donation of City
funds for any community and/or charitable cause or event.
   (b)   Nothing in this legislation shall prohibit the use of “in kind”
services from the City such as free use of City facilities, use of City owned
equipment, and use of City services.
   (c)   Nothing in this legislation shall prohibit the use of City funds to
promote the City of Twinsburg in advertisements in magazines, programs, and
community publications provided that such use promotes the City and not
individuals.
(Ord. 69-2007.  Passed 6-26-07.)
CHAPTER 112
Conflict of Interest Regulations
112.01   Conflict of interest.
112.02   Prohibitions during employment.
112.03   Manner of presenting complaint.
112.99   Penalty.
   112.01  CONFLICT OF INTEREST.
   (a)   All elected and appointed officials of the City of Twinsburg are
subject to and shall comply with the applicable ethics statutes of the State of
Ohio.
   (b)   All elected officials shall publicly disclose on the official records
of the Municipality any conflict of interest that he or she may have pertaining
to any legislation pending before Council prior to its reading.Such a conflict
of interest shall deprive the elected official of any right to participate in
discussions and to vote on such legislation.The failure of any elected official
to make such disclosure shall not affect the validity of the action of Council
upon such legislation. However, if an elected official has failed to disclose a
conflict of interest pertaining to legislation which has been formally acted
upon by Council and the vote of such elected official was determinative of the
success or failure of the legislation, then the legislation may be voided by
subsequent action of Council, upon disclosure or discovery of the conflict of
interest of the elected official. 
(Ord. 47-2007.  Passed 4-24-07.)
   112.02  PROHIBITIONS DURING EMPLOYMENT.
   No officer, member of Council, Mayor or member of any board or commission,
employee, or appointee of the City shall:
   (a)   Gain financially from any contract, job, work or service with or for
the City, nor in any contract, job, work or service for which approval thereof
will be required by elected officials or any officer, employee or appointee to
any board or commission, nor in the profit or emoluments thereof, nor in the
expenditure of any money on the part of the City other than in his fixed
compensation and expenses.  Any contract with the City in which any officer or
employee is or becomes financially interested may be declared void by the Mayor
or Council.Such interest shall disqualify any such officer or employee from
holding office, in addition to the other penalties provided by law;
   (b)   Act, directly or indirectly, as attorney, agent, broker, finder,
engineer, architect or employee or in any other capacity, in behalf of any
private person, firm or corporation interested, directly or indirectly, in any
manner whatsoever, in any contract, work or business, or the sale or
acquisition of any property, the cost of which is payable from City funds;
   (c)   Engage in the practice of law or represent or appear in behalf of an
individual or individuals in any court in any matter or controversy in which
the City is or may become a party, except on behalf of the City as an officer
or employee, or voluntarily give opinion evidence against the interests of the
City in any litigation in which the City is a party; or
   (d)   Appear before any board of commission of the City as counsel, attorney
or agent, except that the Mayor or a member of Council may appear in behalf of
a constituent or constituents without compensation therefore, or in the
performance of a public obligations or official duties.
   (e)   Subsections (a) and (b) do not apply to a public contract in which a
City officer, member of Council or member of any board or commission, employee,
or appointee has an interest, when all of the following apply:
      (1)   The subject of the public contract is necessary supplies or
services for the City;
      (2)   The supplies or services are unobtainable elsewhere for the same or
lower cost, or are being furnished to the City as part of a continuing course
of dealing established prior to the public official’s becoming associated with
the City;
      (3)   The treatment accorded the City is either preferential to or the
same as that accorded other customers or clients in similar transactions; and
      (4)   The entire transaction is conducted at arm’s length, with full
knowledge by the City, through its Mayor and the Council, of the interest of
the public official, and the public official takes no part in the deliberations
or decisions of the City with respect to the public contract.
   (f)   For purposes of this section, “public official” means any officer, the
Mayor, member of Council or member of any board or commission, employee or
appointee of the City of Twinsburg.
   (g)   For purposes of this section, “contract” means any agreement, job,
work, services or furnishing of materials or supplies from which there is
derived any profit, emoluments or compensation of any kind, whether monetary or
in kind.
      (Ord. 47-2007.  Passed 4-24-07.)
   112.03  MANNER OF PRESENTING COMPLAINT.
   All complaints of conflict of interest shall be made in writing in affidavit
form and delivered to either the Law Director or the Clerk of Council. If a
person so accused is an employee of the City, the Law Director shall cause a
copy of the complaint to be served upon the accused and a copy to the Civil
Service Commission. The Law Director shall investigate the truth of the charges
and take such disciplinary action as the case may require. If the accused is an
elected or appointed official of the City, the Law Director or Clerk of Council
shall cause facsimile copies of the complaint to be distributed to members of
Council and to the accused. Council shall, within thirty (30) days, conduct a
preliminary hearing, in private, to determine whether there exists a probable
cause to believe that the charges against the accused are true. If Council, by
a three- fourths (3/4) margin, shall decide that there exists probable cause to
believe the charges are true and are supported by reasonable and credible
evidence, after giving the accused a full opportunity to be heard in reply,
shall take such disciplinary action as the law permits, depending upon the
circumstances of the case, to enforce the ordinances of the City and the laws
of the State of Ohio relating to conflict of interest. Council shall, at the
next regular Council meeting following such affirmative vote finding the
probability of conflict of interest, make such notation, recommendation,
resolution or ordinances as they shall desire at the Council meeting and have
the same recorded upon the minutes. If Council shall not find the probability
of a conflict of interest by such vote, then the accusation shall not be made
public. During the pendency of such proceedings and unless and until the matter
be recorded upon the minutes of Council during a regular meeting, no person
shall cause to be made public any of the charges, replies or information
obtained for or against the accused nor shall they invade the privacy of the
accused pending a full and final determination by Council, except as otherwise
provided by State law. Nothing in this section shall be determined to supersede
the laws of the State of Ohio.
(Ord. 47-2007.  Passed 4-24-07.)
   112.99  PENALTY.
   The willful and intentional violation of this section is hereby declared to
be unlawful and upon conviction, the accused shall be found guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree. Nothing herein contained shall prevent the
accused from being prosecuted under any other provision of State law.
(Ord. 47-2007.  Passed 4-24-07.)

   121.01  MINOR PURCHASES AUTHORIZED.
   The Mayor is authorized to make minor purchases of supplies and services
from merchants and suppliers locally, irrespective of the fact that the owner,
partner, stockholders or employees of the seller may be an appointee or an
employee of the Municipality, subject to the following restrictions hereinafter
set forth, if in his opinion it is more expedient and economical to do so,
taking into account the travel time and transportation costs.
   (a)   Such purchases herein authorized shall be made only if the item or
service needed cannot be obtained from another local merchant or supplier upon
like terms and conditions.
   (b)   The purchases herein authorized shall not exceed fifty dollars
($50.00) at any one time and shall not exceed an annual total of one thousand
dollars ($1,000) from any one merchant or supplier.
   (c)   The purchases herein authorized shall not under any circumstances be
made from any establishment in which any elected official of the Municipality
has a direct or indirect financial interest. 
(Ord. 17-1960.  Passed 3-9-60.)
   121.02  MAILING AND PRINTING EXPENDITURES AUTHORIZED.
   The Mayor is authorized to incur printing and mailing expenditures, to the
extent funds therefor are available, on behalf of the Municipality so long as
the same shall be for a general public purpose and not designed to influence
public opinion.  The following purposes are declared to be of a general public
interest and nature authorized herein although such expenditures are not
necessarily limited thereto:
   (a)   The Mayor’s Annual Report.
   (b)   The Mayor’s newsletter of a factual and objective report nature.
   (c)   The newsletter depicting new municipal services available.
   (d)   The sampling of public opinion on various issues of a general and
permanent nature including but not limited to issues of annexation, the need
for public utilities on an assessment basis in various districts within the
Municipality, suggested Charter amendments, proposed new municipal services or
capital improvements, etc. 
(Ord. 36-1966.  Passed 5-10-66.)
   121.03  FINANCIAL REPORT TO COUNCIL.
   The Mayor, or the Finance Director, shall present a report of the financial
condition of the City to Council at least once a month during a regular Council
meeting.
(Ord. 13-1982.  Passed 3-9-82.)
   121.04  PARTICIPATION IN STATE COOPERATIVE PURCHASING.
   (a)    The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City to be
bound by all contract terms and conditions as the Department of Administrative
Service, Office of State Purchasing prescribes. Such terms and conditions may
include a reasonable fee to cover the administrative costs which the Department
of Administrative Services incurs as a result of the City's participation in a
contract. Further, that the Mayor does hereby agree to be bound by all such
terms and conditions.
   (b)    The Mayor is hereby authorized to agree in the name of the City to
directly pay the vendor, under such State contract in which it participates,
for items it receives pursuant to the contract, and that the Mayor does hereby
agree to directly pay the vendor.
(Res. 17-1988. Passed 1-26-88.)
   121.05  COMMUNITY IMPROVEMENT CORPORATION.
   The Mayor is hereby authorized to create the Twinsburg Community Improvement
Corporation and file appropriate Articles of Incorporation and related
documents with the State of Ohio.  (Ord. 16-2013.  Passed 5-14-13.)

   127.01  INVESTMENT OF FUNDS.
   Whenever there are moneys in the Treasury of the Municipality which will not
be required to be used by the Municipality, such moneys may, in lieu of being
deposited in a bank or banks, be invested in obligations of the Municipality,
or in such other bonds or obligations as are specified in Ohio R.C. 731.56. 
Such investments shall be managed by the Twinsburg Treasury Investment Board. 
Such Board shall be comprised of the Law Director, the Director of Finance, the
Mayor, and one member of Council.  Such member shall be appointed by Council
for a one-year term.  Investments shall be made in the manner and pursuant to
the terms and provisions set forth in Ohio R.C. 731.56 to 731.59. 
(Ord. 116-1980.  Passed 12-23-80.)
   127.02  PETTY CASH FUNDS.
   (a)   The following departments are hereby authorized to draw warrants from
the General Funds for sums in the amounts set forth herein for making of change
and the payment of such items as said department head may deem proper and
expedient upon the receipt of proper receipts therefore. The petty cash amounts
for each department shall not exceed the following:
 
Department               Petty Cash Amount
Aaron & Moses Restaurant $    600.00
Banquet                  $    200.00
Building Department   $      50.00
Finance Department    $    500.00
Fitness Center        $    300.00

Police Department        $    150.00
Seasonal Rock the Park   $ 4,600.00
Seasonal Water Park   $    300.00
Sewer Department         $      75.00
   (b)   The Department Heads are further authorized, with proper approval from
the Mayor and his/her designate, to replenish such petty cash funds from time
to time, up to the maximums herein stated, from the Appropriate Fund and to
charge expenditures made to their proper accounts.  (Ord.  87-2019.  Passed 11-
12-19.)
   127.03  PREPAYMENT OF SPECIAL ASSESSMENT INSTALLMENTS.
   (a)   The Finance Director is hereby authorized to accept prepayment of any
special assessment installments levied by the Municipality payable over a
period of more than one year, all in accordance with Ohio R.C. 5719.16.  Such
prepayment shall be in cash and pertain to all remaining installments of any
such special assessments or reassessments levied by the Municipality as a lien
upon any lot or parcel of land and which installments are not yet due.  Such
prepayment shall include the payment of interest if such be chargeable in
accordance with the terms of original funding for such improvement whether the
same is done by notes or bonds.  Interest shall be chargeable and not
refundable up to the time of full redemption and satisfaction of the original
funded obligation and shall be chargeable without penalty to the Municipality
for its prepayment of original funding or without forfeiture of interest
amounts prepaid hereunder.
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed upon
receiving such prepayment of installments as are mentioned in subsection (a)
hereof to certify such fact to the County Auditor who shall thereupon cancel
such installments as a lien upon his records.
(Res. 41-1964.  Passed 4-14-64.)
   127.04  SEPARATE OFFICES OF FINANCE DIRECTOR AND CLERK ESTABLISHED.
   Council, pursuant to Section
7.01 of the Municipal Charter, hereby declares that effective January 1, 1963,
the positions of Finance Director and Clerk shall become two separate and
distinct positions both of which shall entail individually such duties as are
separately enumerated in Section
7.02 and
3.09(B) of the Charter and such other and incidental duties as may be
prescribed by the Mayor in order to carry out the full intent of such
subsections. 
(Ord. 78-1962.  Passed 11-27-62.)
   127.05  DEPUTY FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   There is hereby created the official office and title of Deputy Finance
Director.  The Deputy Finance Director shall act in lieu of and in place of the
Finance Director during his absence for any reason whatsoever and in the event
the office of Finance Director shall become vacant.  All of the Deputy’s
actions shall be deemed as official acts of the Finance Director when made in
his absence, and therefore, shall be the official acts of the City as relates
to those duties and responsibilities imposed upon the Finance Director and now
imposed upon the Deputy Finance Director as set forth and defined in Section
7.02 of the Charter.  The Deputy Finance Director shall have all powers,
privileges and duties conferred upon the Finance Director when acting in his
absence and stead.  Appointment to such position shall be made by the Mayor. 
The position shall be a non-civil service position and the person who holds it
shall be subject to removal by the Mayor.  The person holding the position of
Deputy Finance Director may also hold an additional official job classification
or description within the City which shall constitute the whole or entire
compensation for such office, or Council, at its option, may provide for
additional or independent compensation for such office.  The Deputy Finance
Director shall perform all of those duties referred to in Section
7.02 of the Charter and such other assignments as may be delegated by the
Mayor.
(Ord. 117-1975.  Passed 12-9-75.)
   127.06  CITY OFFICERS AUTHORIZING SIGNATURES.
   (a)   The lawful manner of executing, endorsing and signing the drafts,
warrants, checks, vouchers and all other fiscal instruments pertaining to the
City shall be by the signature and the added countersignature of the following
City officers:
      (1)   The Mayor
      (2)   The Director of Finance
and in the absence of any of the above then one or more of the above signatures
plus any one of the following signatures of the persons holding the following
City office shall be lawful:
      (1)    The Assistant Finance Director
      (2)   The Clerk of Council
      (3)   The President of Council
   (b)   Deposits as well as withdrawals upon the Municipal accounts may be
made upon the same signature procedure as set forth in subsection (a) hereof.
(Ord. 10-2018.  Passed 1-23-18.)
   127.07  CAPITAL IMPROVEMENT BOARD.
   (a)   Established.  There is hereby established and created a Capital
Improvement Board comprised of five qualified electors, one from each ward of
the City holding no other public office and appointed by Council.
   (b)   Term of Office.  The residents appointed by Council shall serve a two-
year term.
   (c)   Meetings.  The Board shall meet as directed by Council and/or the
Mayor and is authorized to meet upon the concurrence of a majority of its
members.  It shall meet at last four (4) times per year.
   (d)   Duties.  The Board shall advise Council and the Administration.  The
Board shall consider all proposed capital improvements and make recommendations
concerning same.  The Board shall coordinate its activities with the various
boards, committees and commissions established by Council.  Copies of all
reports and recommendations shall be filed with the Clerk of Council.  (Ord.
74-2010.  Passed 5-11-10.)
   127.08  REAL ESTATE TAX ABATEMENT PROGRAM.
   (EDITOR’S NOTE:  See the Clerk of Council for the latest Municipal policy
regarding Real Estate Tax Abatement.)
   127.09  CONSENSUAL LIEN PROGRAM.
   Any property owner subject to the levy of a special assessment for the
installation of sewer or water line not required to immediately connect to such
sewer or water line may participate in the Consensual Lien Program under the
following terms and conditions.
   (a)   Within thirty days of the publishing of the Notice of the Assessing
Ordinance the property owner shall either pay the assessment or enter into a
consensual lien.
   (b)   Said consensual lien shall be in form provided by the City of
Twinsburg and shall provide that the full amount of the assessment and any
connection or tap in fees required by law shall be due and payable upon the
occurrence of any of the following:
      (1)   Connection to the subject improvements;
      (2)   Sale of the property subject to the consensual lien;
      (3)   Failure of the septic system in the case of sanitary sewer
improvement or failure of the water well in the case of water line improvement.
   (c)   The consensual lien document shall be recorded with the appropriate
Summit County official and shall be in full force as a lien against the subject
property until discharged by the City of Twinsburg according to its terms.
   (d)   Transfer of an interest in property between or among tenants in common
shall not be considered as sale of the property for the purposes of paragraph
(b)(2) herein. 
(Ord. 61-2000.  Passed 6-13-00.)
   127.10  FIXED ASSET POLICY.
   EDITOR’S NOTE: The “Fixed Asset Policy” attached to Ordinance 53-2015 and
incorporated herein as Exhibit “A” is adopted to provide for the proper
accounting and reporting of the City’s fixed assets in an accurate and timely
manner.

   131.01  VOLUNTEER FIREMEN'S DEPENDENTS BOARD.
   Under provisions of Ohio R.C. Chapter 146, a Volunteer Firemen's Dependents
Board is established, to be constituted and to have such powers and duties as
set forth in the Ohio Revised Code.
(Ord. 51-1957. Passed 11-1-57.)
   131.02  POLICE RESIDENCY REQUIREMENTS.
   Section intentionally left blank.
   131.03  DIVISION OF POLICE ORGANIZATION.
   (a)   In accordance with Section
7.03 of the Charter, the following ranks, positions, offices and organization
are hereby established, together with authorized personnel, within the Division
of Police:
 
Title                                 No. of Personnel Authorized
Chief of Police                       1
Assistant Chief                       As determined
Lieutenants                           by
Sergeants                             Mayor

Patrol Officers (full or part-time)
Full-time Radio Dispatcher (I and II)
   (b)   The Mayor may authorize the future employment of part-time personnel,
consistent with the monetary appropriations available from Council.  All
regular, full-time personnel below the rank of Assistant Chief shall be
appointed and promoted in accordance with the Twinsburg Civil Service
Commission rules and regulations.  All duties performed by personnel within
such Division shall be prescribed by the Mayor and Chief of Police and shall be
set forth in the Twinsburg Police Manual which is hereby fully adopted by this
reference; the officially adopted copy of which as amended by the Police Chief
shall be kept in both the Offices of the Chief of Police and the Clerk of
Council.  All part-time personnel shall be within the unclassified civil
service status and non-bargaining unit positions of the City and shall be
appointed at the discretion of the Mayor consistent with the monetary
appropriations available from Council provided, however, that the Mayor may
require certain testing and minimum qualifying conditions to receive an
original appointment as a part-time employee, but such employees may be
dismissed by the Mayor with or without cause.
     
   (c)   Should the present Twinsburg Police Manual be, in any manner,
inconsistent with the foregoing, the Chief of Police is hereby directed to
amend the Manual in accord herewith.  (Ord. 44-2011.  Passed 4-26-11.)
   131.04  DIVISION OF FIRE ORGANIZATION.
     (a)     In accordance with Section
7.03 of the Charter, the following ranks, positions, offices and organization
are hereby established, together with authorized personnel, within the Division
of Fire:
 
Title                                         No.  of Personnel Authorized
Fire Chief                                    1
Assistant Fire Chief
Captain(s)
Lieutenant(s)                                 As determined by Mayor
Firefighter/Paramedic(s): (full or part-time)
Cadet/Recruit(s)
All regular, full-time personnel below the rank of Assistant Fire Chief shall
be appointed and promoted in accordance with the Twinsburg Civil Service
Commission rules and regulations.  All duties performed by personnel within
such Division shall be prescribed by the Mayor and Fire Chief and shall be set
forth in the Standard Operating Procedures which are hereby fully adopted by
this reference; the officially adopted copy of which as amended by the Fire
Chief shall be kept in both the Offices of the Fire Chief and the Clerk of
Council. The Mayor may authorize the future employment of part-time and cadet/
recruit personnel, consistent with the monetary appropriations available from
Council.  All part-time and cadet/recruit personnel shall be within the
unclassified civil service status and non-bargaining unit positions of the City
and shall be appointed at the discretion of the Mayor consistent with the
monetary appropriations available from Council provided, however, that the
Mayor may require certain testing and minimum qualifying conditions to receive
an original appointment as a part-time or cadet/recruit employee, but such
employees may be dismissed by the Mayor with or without cause.
     (b)     Except as otherwise provided herein, such firefighter/ Paramedics
shall be at least twenty-one (21) years of age. Determination of whether
candidates are suitable for appointment shall be made by the Fire Chief after a
medical and physical examination has been made in a manner prescribed by the
Fire Chief and approved by the Safety Director. A cadet/recruit may commence
service at eighteen (18) years of age, and must possess a high school diploma
or G.E.D.
   (c)     All appointments made under subsection (a) hereof shall be for a
probationary period as set forth in the current contract between the City of
Twinsburg and the Fire Department Labor Organization or Chapter
147 herein, whichever is applicable. All appointments and promotions of full-
time regular fire personnel, below the rank of Assistant Fire Chief, shall be
by Civil Service Commission rules and regulations.
     (d)     The Fire Chief shall:
      (1)     Take charge and custody of all fire apparatus and equipment and
supervise the maintenance thereof so that the same may be in good order and
condition and ready for use at all times;
      (2)     Have full control of the Fire Division and its members during all
fires and emergencies and may at any time during a fire call or emergency, call
upon any citizen or citizens to perform labor, which in his judgment is
necessary to aid in the extinguishing of fires; and
      (3)       Have such other and further duties and responsibilities as may
be provided by law or assigned to him by the Director of Public Safety.
     (e)     Each regular firefighter and officer shall receive as compensation
that amount approved by Council.
     (f)     The Fire Division created hereby is a governmental unit and shall
have no official connection whatsoever with any fire companies privately
organized for any purpose, other than the fact that its members may also be
members of such companies or contracts with companies as might be authorized by
Council, if any.
     (g)     The Fire Division hereby created shall be bound by any contract
that may be made by Council with any other municipality or township or any
other party with which the City is authorized to legally contract according to
the terms thereof.
     (h)     The Fire Chief and the Safety Director shall be responsible for
the personnel morale and general efficiency of the Division.  The Fire Chief
and Safety Director shall formulate and submit to Council any additional rules
and regulations to govern the Division and upon approval thereof by Council a
copy thereof shall be furnished to each member of the Division and to the Clerk
of Council, which copy the Clerk shall file in the permanent records of the
City.
       (i)       The Fire Chief shall assemble the officers and firefighters
for the purpose of instruction and drill in the operation and understanding of
all phases of the work which have a bearing upon good firefighters to maintain
proficiency as recommended by State and National Standards for Fire, EMS,
HAZMAT and Special Operations performed by the Fire Department.
     (j)      The Division may organize for social interests providing there is
no interference with its general efficiency and provided that none of the
provisions of their social organization shall be in conflict with any of the
terms of this section and expenditure of moneys shall be in accordance with
standards established by the Bureau of Public Inspection, Ohio State Auditor's
Office.  No Division funds, however received, may be used for social events and
must be deposited with the Finance Director except outright gifts and
contributions not involving the use of Fire Division personnel or equipment as
consideration therefore.
   (k)   The Fire Chief is hereby required to cause inspections to be made for
all buildings and premises within the Fire District of Twinsburg, except those
buildings used exclusively for residential purposes, as determined by the
Occupancy Hazard classifications in the N.F.P.A.'s Fire Protection Handbook,
most current edition each year.  All high hazard occupancies will be inspected
at least twice each year and all low and medium hazard occupancies will be
inspected at least once each year.  The Fire Prevention Bureau will classify
all occupancies by hazard classification to meet this requirement.  The Fire
Chief and/or his inspectors are further required to serve written notice upon
the owner of any building or premises to abate, within a specified time, any
and all fire hazards or hazards that may be found therein or thereon.
   (l)   Any person, firm or corporation so served with an order to abate any
fire hazard or hazards, shall comply with such order forthwith, and thereupon
notify the Fire Chief or the Fire Marshal.
     (m)     All personal cars of Fire Division members may be classified as
public safety vehicles as set forth in Section
301.27 of the Traffic Code provided provisions of Section
337.19 of the Traffic Code are observed.  A record of such vehicles shall be
prepared by the Fire Chief and filed with the Twinsburg Police Department.
     (n)    It is hereby made the special duty of the Police Chief, policemen
and such other peace officers as are on duty at the time, to respond to all
fire alarms and assist the Fire Division in the protection of the life of the
Citizens of the City and the property therein, and the property of the Fire
Division and in controlling and regulating traffic and maintaining order. 
(Ord.  42-2020.  Passed 5-26-20.)
   131.05  POLICE AGE REQUIREMENTS.
   No person shall be eligible to receive an original appointment as a police
patrolman within the Division of Police, Department of Public Safety of the
City unless he or she has attained the age of twenty-one years and has passed a
physical examination given by a licensed physician showing that he or she meets
the physical requirements necessary to perform the duties of such office.  The
appointment authority shall, prior to making any such appointment, file with
the Police and Firemens’ Disability and Pension Fund, a copy of the report of
findings of such licensed physician.  The professional fees for such physical
examination shall be paid by the City. 
(Ord. 49-2006.  Passed 5-23-06.)
   131.06  AUTHORIZATION OF INVESTIGATION EXPENDITURES.
   The Chief of Police is hereby authorized and directed to make and approve
such necessary investigative and evidence gathering expenses as he, in his sole
discretion deems appropriate, in the prosecution of persons engaged in criminal
activities within the corporate limits, which miscellaneous moneys shall be
paid from the Miscellaneous Expense Account of the Twinsburg Police Department,
being part of the General Fund. The Chief of Police shall approve by vouchers
all such expenses for the purposes herein mentioned and shall refer to the case
involved, the date and time that the expenditure was incurred, the purpose for
each expenditure, to whom such moneys were paid and such other pertinent data
as can readily be verified by audit in the future.
(Ord. 42-1974. Passed 3-12-74.)
   131.07  JURISDICTION OF SAFETY FORCES OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a)    The safety forces of the City of Twinsburg including police, fire and
building officials are authorized to exercise jurisdiction and to enforce all
laws and regulations of the City of Twinsburg on all property owned by the City
beyond its limits.
   (b)    Law enforcement officers are empowered to make arrests and issue
citations and to invoke the jurisdiction of the Stow Municipal Court on such
property.
(Ord. 44-2011.  Passed 4-26-11.)

   133.01  CREATION.
   The position of Municipal Engineer is hereby created and established within
the unclassified service of the Municipality.
(Ord. 11-1984. Passed 1-24-84.)
   133.02  QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Engineer shall be a civil engineer and registered as a professional
engineer as required by Ohio R.C. Chapter 4733.
(Ord. 30-1959. Passed 5-1-59.)
   133.03  TERM OF EMPLOYMENT. (DELETED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Former Section
133.03 was repealed and deleted pursuant to Ordinance 11-1984, passed January
24, 1984.)
   133.04  DUTIES.
   The Engineer shall:
   (a)    Prepare all necessary plans, profiles, specifications and estimates
of every kind for all public improvements;
   (b)    Serve as the authorized representative of the Municipality and
supervise the execution of public work undertaken by the Municipality pursuant
to plans and specifications approved by Council;
   (c)    Supervise and direct all inspectors and such inspectors shall report
to and receive their instructions from him, relative to the improvements
covered by contract;
   (d)    At the request of the Mayor, furnish plans, specifications and
estimates of cost of all improvements for the guidance of Council and Municipal
officials and for the information and guidance of other persons dealing with
the City;
   (e)    Upon request, make and deliver to the Mayor and Council, reports of
the progress of improvements under his charge;
   (f)   Make his services available to any department of the Municipality upon
approval of the Mayor; (Ord. 86-1978. Passed 7-25-78.)
   (g)    Attend all meetings of Council as required by the Mayor.
      (Ord. 11-1984. Passed 1-24-84.)
   133.05  OFFICE.
   The Mayor may provide an office in the Municipal Building for occupancy by
the Engineer.
   133.06  APPOINTMENT.
   The appointment of the Engineer shall be made by the Mayor.
   133.07  WAGE COORDINATOR.
   (a)    The City Engineer is hereby designated to serve as the Prevailing
Wage Coordinator under Ohio R.C. 4115.071, as pertains to all municipal
contracts involving payment of wages to employees. His duties shall include:
      (1)    The establishment of files of payroll reports to be submitted by
contractors and subcontractors which shall be available for public inspection.
      (2)    To ascertain from each such person at the beginning of the
municipal contract, the dates when payment of wages to employees are to be
made.
      (3)    To receive a complete payroll from contractors or subcontractors
setting forth in detail payments made to employees, hourly rates, job
classifications, fringe benefits, deductions, etc.
      (4)    To establish and follow procedures to monitor compliance hereof by
each contractor and to assure the timely filing of all records by them.
      (5)    Reporting any delinquency to the Mayor.
   (b)    Each contractor and subcontractor doing business with the City shall
be subject to the terms of this section and to Ohio R.C. Chapter 4115 and he
shall comply therewith.
   (c)    Whoever violates this section shall be fined five hundred dollars
($500.00) for a first offense and one thousand dollars ($1,000) for each
subsequent offense.
(Res. 47-1975. Passed 4-22-75.)
