defined at 40 CFR 2.302 shall not be recognized as confidential information and
shall be available to the public without restriction.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.15  PUBLICATION OF USERS IN SIGNIFICANT NONCOMPLIANCE.
   (a)    Significant Non-Compliance.  The Public Works Director shall publish
annually, in a newspaper of general circulation that provides meaningful public
notice within the jurisdictions served by the POTW, a list of the Users which,
at any time during the previous twelve (12) months, were in Significant
Noncompliance with applicable Pretreatment Standards and Requirements. The term
Significant Noncompliance shall be applicable to all Significant Industrial
Users or any other Industrial User that violates Section
913.15(a)(3), (4) and (8)) and shall mean:
      (1)    Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined here as
those in which sixty-six percent (66%) or more of all the measurements taken
from each of an SIU's permitted monitoring points for the same pollutant
parameter taken during a six (6) month period exceed (by any magnitude) a
numeric Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, including Instantaneous Limits as
defined in Section
913.07(d)(17), (See 40 CFR 403.3(1)).
      (2)    Technical Review Criteria (TRC) violations, defined here as those
in which thirty-three percent (33%) or more of wastewater measurements taken
from each of an SIU's permitted monitoring points for each pollutant parameter
during a six- (6-) month period equals or exceeds the product of the numeric
Pretreatment Standard or Requirement including Instantaneous Limits, as defined
by Sections
913.07(d)(17) and
913.08(b), (c) and (d) multiplied by the applicable criteria (1.4 for BOD, TSS,
fats, oils and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH); See 40 CFR
403.3(1).
      (3)    Any other violation of a Pretreatment Standard or Requirement as
defined by Section
913.08(b), (c) and (d)  (Daily Maximum, long-term average, Instantaneous Limit,
or narrative standard) that the Public Works Director determines has caused,
alone or in combination with other discharges, Interference or Pass Through,
including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public; See
40 CFR 403.3(1).
      (4)    Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent endangerment
to the public or to the environment, or has resulted in the Public Works
Director exercise of its emergency authority to halt or prevent such a
discharge;
      (5)    Failure to meet, within ninety (90) days of the scheduled date, a
compliance schedule milestone contained in an individual wastewater discharge
permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction,
or attaining final compliance;
      (6)    Failure to provide within forty-five (45) days after the due date,
any required reports, including baseline monitoring reports, reports on
compliance with categorical Pretreatment Standard deadlines, periodic self-
monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules;
      (7)    Failure to accurately report noncompliance; or
      (8)    Any other violation(s), which may include a violation of Best
Management Practices, which the Public Works Director determines will adversely
affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.16  ADMINISTRATIVE ENFORCEMENT REMEDIES.
   (a)    Notification of Violation.  When the Public Works Director finds that
a User has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an
individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, the Public Works Director may serve upon
that User a written Notice of Violation. Within 15 days of the receipt of such
notice, an explanation of the violation and a plan for the satisfactory
correction and prevention thereof, to include specific required actions, shall
be submitted by the User to the Public Works Director. Submission of such a
plan in no way relieves the User of liability for any violations occurring
before or after receipt of the Notice of Violation. Nothing in this Section
shall limit the authority of the Public Works Director to take any action,
including emergency actions or any other enforcement action, without first
issuing a Notice of Violation.
   (b)    Consent Orders. The Public Works Director may enter into Consent
Orders, assurances of compliance, or other similar documents establishing an
agreement with any User responsible for noncompliance. Such documents shall
include specific action to be taken by the User to correct the noncompliance
within a time period specified by the document. Such documents shall have the
same force and effect as the administrative orders issued pursuant to Sections
 913.16(d) and (e) and shall be judicially enforceable.
   (c)    Show Cause Hearing.  The Public Works Director may order a User which
has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an
individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, to appear before the Public Works
Director and show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be
taken. Notice shall be served on the User specifying the time and place for the
meeting, the proposed enforcement action, the reasons for such action, and a
request that the User show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not
be taken. The notice of the meeting shall be served personally or by registered
or certified mail (return receipt requested) at least seven (7) days prior to
the hearing. Such notice may be served on any Authorized Representative of the
User as defined in Section
913.07(d)(3) and required by Section
913.10 (f)(1). A show cause hearing shall not be a bar against, or prerequisite
for, taking any other action against the User.
   (d)    Compliance Orders.  When the Public Works Director finds that a User
has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an
individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, the Public Works Director may issue an
order to the User responsible for the discharge directing that the User come
into compliance within a specified time. If the User does not come into
compliance within the time provided, sewer service may be discontinued unless
adequate treatment facilities, devices, or other related appurtenances are
installed and properly operated. Compliance orders also may contain other
requirements to address the noncompliance, including additional self-monitoring
and management practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants
discharged to the sewer. A compliance order may not extend the deadline for
compliance established for a Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, nor does a
compliance order relieve the User of liability for any violation, including any
continuing violation. Issuance of a compliance order shall not be a bar
against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the User.
   (e)    Cease and Desist Orders.  When the Public Works Director finds that a
User has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an
individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, or that the User's past violations are
likely to recur, the Public Works Director may issue an order to the User
directing it to cease and desist all such violations and directing the User to:
      (l)    Immediately comply with all requirements; and
      (2)    Take such appropriate remedial or preventive action as may be
needed to properly address a continuing or threatened violation, including
halting operations and/or terminating the discharge. Issuance of a cease and
desist order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any
other action against the User.
   (f)    Administrative Fines.
      (1)    When the Public Works Director finds that a User has violated, or
continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater
discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other Pretreatment Standard
or Requirement, the Public Works Director may fine such User in an amount not
to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000). Such fines shall be assessed on a per-
violation, per-day basis. In the case of monthly or other long-term average
discharge limits, fines may be assessed for each day during the period of
violation.
      (2)    Unpaid charges, fines, and penalties may, after thirty (30)
calendar days, be assessed an additional penalty of ten percent (10%) of the
unpaid balance, and interest may accrue thereafter at a rate of ten percent
(10%) per month. A lien against the User's property may be sought for unpaid
charges, fines, and penalties.
      (3)    Users desiring to dispute such fines must file a written request
for the Public Works Director to reconsider the fine along with full payment of
the fine amount within thirty (30) days of being notified of the fine. Where a
request has merit, the Public Works Director may convene a hearing on the
matter. In the event the User's appeal is successful, the payment, together
with any interest accruing thereto, shall be returned to the User. The Public
Works Director may add the costs of preparing administrative enforcement
actions, such as notices and orders, to the fine.
      (4)    Issuance of an administrative fine shall not be a bar against, or
a prerequisite for taking any other action against the User.
   (g)    Emergency Suspensions.  The Public Works Director may immediately
suspend a User's discharge, after informal notice to the User, whenever such
suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge, which
reasonably appears to present, or cause an imminent or substantial endangerment
to the health or welfare of persons. The Public Works Director may also
immediately suspend a User's discharge, after notice and opportunity to
respond, that threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW, or which
presents, or may present, an endangerment to the environment.
      (1)    Any User notified of a suspension of its discharge shall
immediately stop or eliminate its contribution. In the event of a User's
failure to immediately comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the Public
Works Director may take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate
severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW,
its receiving stream, or endangerment to any individuals. The Public Works
Director may allow the User to recommence its discharge when the User has
demonstrated to the satisfaction of the Public Works Director that the period
of endangerment has passed, unless the termination proceedings in Section
913.16(h) are initiated against the User.
      (2)    A User that is responsible, in whole or in part, for any discharge
presenting imminent endangerment  shall submit a detailed written statement,
describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to
prevent any future occurrence, to the Public Works Director prior to the date
of any show cause or termination hearing under Section
913.16(c) or (h).
   Nothing in this Section shall be interpreted as requiring a hearing prior to
any Emergency Suspension under this Section.
   (h)    Termination of Discharge.  In addition to the provisions in Section
913.11(f) any User who violates the following conditions is subject to
discharge termination:
      (1)    Violation of individual wastewater discharge permit conditions;
      (2)    Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and
characteristics of its discharge;
      (3)    Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater
volume, constituents, and characteristics prior to discharge;
      (4)    Refusal of reasonable access to the User's premises for the
purpose of inspection, monitoring, or sampling; or
      (5)    Violation of the Pretreatment Standards in Section
 913.08(b), (c) and (d).
   Such User will be notified of the proposed termination of its discharge and
be offered an opportunity to show cause under Section
 913.16(c) why the proposed action should not be taken. Exercise of this option
by the Public Works Director shall not be a bar to, or a prerequisite for,
taking any other action against the User.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.17  JUDICIAL ENFORCEMENT REMEDIES.
   (a)    Injunctive Relief.  When the Public Works Director finds that a User
has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an
individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other
Pretreatment Standard or Requirement, the Public Works Director may petition
the appropriate court through the City's Law Director for the issuance of a
temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels
the specific performance of the individual wastewater discharge permit, order,
or other requirement imposed by this chapter on activities of the User. The
Public Works Director may also seek such other action as is appropriate for
legal and/or equitable relief, including a requirement for the User to conduct
environmental remediation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar
against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a User.
   (b)    Civil Penalties.
      (1)    A User who has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of
this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued
hereunder, or any other Pretreatment Standard or Requirement shall be liable to
the City for a maximum civil penalty of one thousand dollars ($1,000) per
violation, per day. In the case of a monthly or other long-term average
discharge limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of the
violation.
      (2)    The Public Works Director may recover reasonable attorneys' fees,
court costs, and other expenses associated with enforcement activities,
including sampling and monitoring expenses, and the cost of any actual damages
incurred by the City.
      (3)    In determining the amount of civil liability, the Court shall take
into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the
extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the
violation, any economic benefit gained through the User's violation, corrective
actions by the User, the compliance history of the User, and any other factor
as justice requires.
      (4)    Filing a suit for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a
prerequisite for, taking any other action against a User.
   (c)    Criminal Prosecution.
      (1)    A User who willfully or negligently violates any provision of this
chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder,
or any other Pretreatment Standard or Requirement shall, upon conviction, be
guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by the maximum fine allowed under State law
per violation, per day, and/or imprisonment.
      (2)    A User who willfully or negligently introduces any substance into
the POTW which causes personal injury or property damage shall, upon
conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and be subject to the maximum fine
allowable under State law, and/or be subject to imprisonment. This penalty
shall be in addition to any other cause of action for personal injury or
property damage available under State law.
      (3)    A User who knowingly makes any false statements, representations,
or certifications in any application, record, report, plan, or other
documentation filed, or required to be maintained, pursuant to this chapter,
individual wastewater discharge permit or order issued hereunder, or who
falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device
or method required under this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a
fine of not more than maximum amount allowable under State law per violation,
per day, and/or imprisonment.
      (4)    In the event of a second conviction, a User shall be punished by a
fine of not more than the maximum amount allowable under State law per
violation, per day, and/or imprisonment.
   (d)    Remedies Nonexclusive. The remedies provided for in this chapter are
not exclusive. The Public Works Director may take any, all, or any combination
of these actions against a noncompliant User. Enforcement of pretreatment
violations will generally be in accordance with the City's enforcement response
plan. However, the Public Works Director may take other action against any User
when the circumstances warrant. Further, the Public Works Director is empowered
to take more than one enforcement action against any noncompliant User. (Ord.
07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.18  BYPASS PROVISION.
   (a)    Bypass.
      (1)   For the purposes of this Section,
         A.    Bypass means the intentional diversion of wastestreams from any
portion of a User's treatment facility.
         B.    Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to
property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become
inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources, which can
reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property
damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production.
      (2)    A User may allow any bypass to occur which does not cause
Pretreatment Standards or Requirements to be violated, but only if it also is
for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses are not
subject to the provision of Section
913.18(a)(3) and (4).
      (3)    Bypass Notifications.
         A.    If a User knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it shall
submit prior notice to the Public Works Director, at least ten (10) days before
the date of the bypass, if possible.
         B.    A User shall submit oral notice to the Public Works Director of
an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable Pretreatment Standards
immediately upon becoming aware of the bypass. A written submission shall also
be provided within five (5) days of the time the User becomes aware of the
bypass. The written submission shall contain a description of the bypass and
its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if
the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to
continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent
reoccurrence of the bypass. The Public Works Director may waive the written
report on a case-by-case basis.
      (4)    Bypass.
         A.    Bypass is prohibited, and the Public Works Director may take an
enforcement action against a User for a bypass, unless:
            1.    Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal
injury, or severe property damage;
            2.    There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as
the use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or
maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not
satisfied if adequate back-up equipment should have been installed in the
exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass, which occurred
during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance; and
            3.    The User submitted notices as required under Section
913.18(a)(3).
         B.    The Public Works Director may approve an anticipated bypass,
after considering its adverse effects, if the Public Works Director determines
that it will meet the three conditions listed in Section
 913.18(a)(4)A.
            (Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.19  MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS.
   (a)   Pretreatment Charges and Fees. The City may adopt reasonable fees for
reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the City's Pretreatment
Program, which may include:
      (1)    Fees for wastewater discharge permit applications including the
cost of processing such applications;
      (2)    Fees for monitoring, inspection, and surveillance procedures
including the cost of collection and analyzing a User's discharge, and
reviewing monitoring reports and certification statements submitted by Users;
      (3)    Fees for reviewing and responding to accidental discharge
procedures and construction;
      (4)    Fees for filing appeals;
      (5)    Fees to recover administrative and legal costs associated with the
enforcement activity taken by the Public Works Director to address IU
noncompliance; and
      (6)    Other fees as the City may deem necessary to carry out the
requirements contained herein. These fees relate solely to the matters covered
by this chapter and are separate from all other fees, fines, and penalties
chargeable by the City.
   (b)    Severability.  If any provision of this chapter is invalidated by any
court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions shall not be affected
and shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.20  SATELLITE SEWER DISCHARGE CONTROL PROGRAM; PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)    The SSDCP shall be administrated by the Wastewater Treatment Plant
Superintendent or an authorized representative as appointed by the Public Works
Director. the Public Works Director and City Engineer shall assist the
wastewater Treatment Plant Superintendent with this program.
   (b)    The SSDCP shall be implemented through the issuance of Satellite
Community Discharge Permits. The Permits shall delineate, among other things,
the elimination, up to the specified storm event design, of sanitary sewer
overflows (SSOs), installation of flow meters, implementation of Sanitary Sewer
Evaluation Survey (SSES) and Best Management Practices (BMP).
   (c)    Each community shall, as a condition of its Permit, be required to
undertake appropriate Best Management Practices (BMP) for control/operation of
its sanitary sewer system.
   (d)    Each community shall immediately identify and disclose to the City as
soon as any and all sanitary sewer or combined sewer overflow points known or
which become known to the community and which are not included in the
community's permit.
   (e)    The community shall be solely responsible for projects set forth in
its Community Compliance Schedule identified in its Satellite Community
Discharge Permit.
   (f)    No new sanitary sewer or combined sewer overflows. No community
overflows shall exist except those that are controlled in accordance with the
Satellite Community Discharge Permit.
   (g)    Each community shall maintain a current map of all sanitary sewers
and combined sewer tributary to the City of Twinsburg.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-10-09.)
   913.21  SATELLITE COMMUNITY DISCHARGE PERMIT.
   (a)    The City shall issue permits to satellite Communities with
requirements, conditions and schedules as necessary to achieve the purpose of
this chapter.
   (b)    The City shall notify a Satellite Community by certified mail of
actions the community shall be required to undertake under authority of this
chapter and the applicable sewer agreement. The Permit shall contain or require
the following information at a minimum:
      (1)   General Conditions.
      (2)    Satellite Community Compliance Schedule.
   (c)    The City shall notify a Satellite Community by certified mail of the
schedule for preparation and submittal of the community Fact Sheet with
revisions, if required, and Community Compliance Plan identifying the means by
which the community intends to achieve its Community Compliance Schedule.
   (d)    Upon approval by the City of a Community Compliance Plan, such plan
shall be deemed incorporated into the respective Satellite Community Discharge
Permit for all purposes of the Sewer Use Code. Failure of a Satellite community
to obtain City approval of a plan within ninety (90) days of the required
submittal date shall be deemed a circumstance for initiation of enforcement
action pursuant to Sections
913.23 and
913.24.
   (e)   Permit Modifications, Suspension or Revocation.  After notice and
opportunity for a hearing, the Permit may be modified, suspended or revoked by
the Public Works Director in whole or in part during its term. The City shall
retain the right of revision to amend the Code or the granted permit. In the
event of said modification or amendment, the City shall notify the Satellite
community not less than thirty (30) days prior to the effective date of such
modification or amendment to the Permit. The Satellite Community may at any
time request a modification of any part of this Permit. The request for
modification should be received by the City at least ninety (90) days before
the date on which it is desired that the modification become effective.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.22  SATELLITE COMMUNITY COMPLIANCE SCHEDULE.
   The City shall develop general guidance and evaluation procedures regarding
the Community Compliance Schedule. The Public Works Director shall develop the
guidance and evaluation procedures and revise as required.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.23  SATELLITE COMMUNITY DISCHARGE MONITORING PROGRAM.
   (a)    The Satellite Community, in response to the Permit issued under this
program and subject tp City approval, shall develop a maintenance and
monitoring program. The monitoring program shall be designed to determine the
contributing flow to the City of Twinsburg sanitary sewer system.
   (b)    The City shall have the authority to conduct monitoring for
verification and other purposes within the Satellite community sanitary sewer
system.
   (c)    The Satellite Community shall provide an Annual Report as detailed in
their Permit and shall be submitted by April 1 of each calendar year. Monthly
monitoring and reporting requirements may be required by the City.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.24  SATELLITE COMMUNITY DISCHARGE PROGRAM MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS.
   (a)    All communities subject to this code shall retain and preserve any
records, books, documents, memoranda, reports, correspondence and any and all
summaries thereof relating to planning, design, maintenance, monitoring
sampling, financing and legislative action on the part of a community in
connection with its compliance or noncompliance with its Permit and related
Community Compliance Schedule in accordance with all local, state and federal
law and regulations.
   (b)    The provisions of this portion of this Sewer Use Code consisting of
Sections
913.21 through
913.24 inclusive are intended to be read in conjunction with and to complement
and supplement other provisions of the Sewer Use Code and applicable agreement,
all of which remain fully applicable to the Satellite Communities covered
hereunder.
   (c)   By discharging to the sanitary sewer system of the City, the Satellite
Community agrees to comply with all terms and regulations of the City and to be
bounded by said terms, conditions and regulations.
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.25  SATELLITE COMMUNITY DISCHARGE PROGRAM ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)    The City may initiate enforcement action against a Satellite
Community for violation of any provision of this chapter, but not limited to,
the Satellite Communities' failure to:
      (1)    Implement projects on a permit-required Community Compliance
Schedule.
      (2)    Follow Best Management Practices as specified in their Permit.
      (3)    Properly respond to a request for evidence of progress or
explanation.
      (4)    Produce a sanitary sewer map as required by the Permit
      (5)    Submit an approvable Community Compliance Plan or Fact Sheet in a
timely manner.
      (6)    Prevent the creation of a new sanitary sewer overflow.
   (b)    The City may take any enforcement action available in the chapter,
including but not limited to, Administrative Enforcement Remedies (
913.16) and Judicial Enforcement Remedies (
913.17). By definition and for use of these enforcement sections, a
“discharger” is defined as a person or governmental entity as defined in the
chapter including a "Satellite Community”.  The enforcement action may be taken
alone or in combination as necessary to effectuate the achievement of the
Community Compliance Schedule. 
(Ord. 07-2009.  Passed 2-11-09.)
   913.26  EFFECTIVE DATE.
   This chapter shall be in full force and effect immediately following its
passage, approval, and publication, as provided by law.
(Ord. 07-2009. Passed 2-11-09.)
CHAPTER 915
Water Charges
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The Municipality contracts with the City of Cleveland for
water services. Ordinance 78-1964 created the Saints Cosmas and Damian Parish
Trust Fund in order to reimburse the Catholic Diocese of Cleveland and the
Saints Cosmas and Damian Parish for the construction of municipal water lines.
Ordinance 49-1965 created "tap and use" fees for lands benefited under Project
"64" improvements.
   There are no sections in Chapter
915. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross references
and any future legislation.

         Power to regulate water rates - see Ohio R.C. 743.26
         Contract for water supply - see Ohio R.C. 743.24

   917.01  CONSENT FOR ERECTION OF LINES, STRUCTURES.
   No person operating a public utility shall erect or maintain any lines or
structures in, over or through any streets, alleys, lanes, lands, squares and
public places of the Municipality without first securing the consent of the
Municipality by a duly enacted resolution of Council.
(Ord. 32-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   917.02  FILING REQUEST; PLANNING COMMISSION'S RECOMMENDATIONS.
   The request for the consent required by Section
903.01 shall be filed with the Mayor, who shall refer same to the Planning
Commission for their consideration, who shall, within a reasonable time, report
their recommendations to Council.
(Ord. 32-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   917.03  CONFORMITY WITH ZONING REGULATIONS; CONSTRUCTION PERMIT.
   If consent is given for construction of buildings or structures necessary to
such transmission lines as transformer stations, booster stations, substations,
power stations or control or regulating centers, they may be erected in
conformity with the zoning regulations of the district where located and shall
be enclosed on all sides with at least a chain link fence a minimum of eight
feet high and further protected by barbed wire at the top of such fence,
properly screened by shrubs to protect the health, safety and welfare of the
public. The building or structure and the appurtenances thereto shall be
approved by the Planning Commission before a construction permit is issued by
the Division of Buildings.
(Ord. 32-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   917.04  COMMUNITY ANTENNA TELEVISION.
   (a)    Community antenna television systems are hereby declared and
recognized to be public utilities when operated or when such operation is
contemplated within the Municipality. "Operation" means any system for the
transmission, amplification, receipt, reproduction, projection or creation of a
television picture or image within the Municipality and shall include all
conduits, wires, electrical transmission or reception devices, fixed antenna
and transmitter locations, electrical generating equipment and any and all
other equipment appurtenant to the television industry.
   (b)    Any person operating or attempting to operate such a community
antenna television system shall obtain a franchise for such utility operation
from Council, subject to such reasonable regulations for the operation of such
utility as may be imposed by Council, in consideration of the recommendations
of the Planning Commission pursuant to Section
 903.02.
(Ord. 18-1966. Passed 3-22-66.)
   917.05  REGULATIONS GOVERNING UTILITY SHUT-OFF.
   No person employed by or operating a public utility supplying natural gas or
electric energy to customers within the corporate limits shall cause the same
to be shut-off unless:
   (a)    A real and present emergency exists in bulk supplies affecting all
similar uses alike.
   (b)    A real and present emergency exists affecting the occupancy safety of
specific premises.
   (c)    A thirty (30) day prior written notice of pending shut-off is served
upon the occupant and owner of the premises and the Safety Director sets forth
the specific reasons for such shut-off action.
   In the event any subsequent shut-off is made due to delinquent payments for
energy furnished, and thereafter, such account becomes current, the utility
company shall immediately restore such service.
(Ord. 37-1977. Passed 2-22-77.)
   917.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00). Every day during which such violation continues
shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 32-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)

CHAPTER 919
Municipal Refuse/Recyclables Collection

CROSS REFERENCES
      Collection and disposal of refuse - see Ohio R.C. 715.43, 717.01
      Disposal of rubbish on public and private ways - see GEN. OFF.
521.10
      Pollution of watercourses - see GEN. OFF.
521.08,
521.09
      Burning rubbish - see FIRE PREV. Ch.
1503
   919.01  INTERVALS OF COLLECTION.
   The City of Twinsburg shall provide for a Refuse/Recycle collection service
to those residential inhabitants of the City herein defined. Refuse and
Recyclable material shall be collected one day per week as established by the
City. In the event that a holiday occurs on a day prior to the established
collection day, collection will be rescheduled for the following day. Holidays
occurring after the established collection day will not affect the collection
schedule. All containers shall be loaded and be upon the curb for pickup by 7:
00 a.m. on any day of collection.  (Ord. 40- 2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   919.02  REFUSE DEFINED.
   "Refuse", for purposes of municipal collection, means rejected waste matter
accumulating in residential dwellings of one or two families in the normal
course of household affairs and includes such items as rags, straw, excelsior,
old clothes, shoes, scraps of wood, rubber, carpets, or discarded household
appliances, toys, oil cloth, trimmings and clippings, building materials,
discarded hardware, cooking utensils, crockery, enameled ware and other usual
household discards so long as they can be placed in a container as hereinafter
provided and not weighing more than 50 lbs. Hazardous waste as defined by the
US Environmental Protection Agency or appropriate agency of the State of Ohio
to be hazardous shall not be collected.  (Ord. 40-2013.  Passed 4-9- 13.)
   919.03  RECYCLABLES DEFINED
   "Recyclables" for the purpose of municipal collection means those materials
that can be collected and processed into new products. Recyclable materials
include, but are not limited to:  glass, paper, metal, plastic, textiles,
electronics, oils, anti-freeze fluid, and cardboard.
   (a)   Plastics containing the recycle logo and a number between 1 and 7. 
Items included in this classification are soda bottles, salad dressing bottles,
milk and water jugs, laundry and cleaning product containers and shampoo
bottles.
   (b)   Glass (all colors) includes juice, soda and water bottles, beer and
wine bottles, food jars.
   (c)   Metal includes tin food cans, aluminum and steel beverage cans,
aluminum foil, and pie pans.
   (d)   Newspaper/Cardboard includes all newspapers and color inserts,
corrugated cardboard, drink boxes, milk and juice boxes, food boxes, junk mail,
and magazines.
   Excluded Items:
   Plastic bags, plastic containers used for motor oil, automotive parts,
paint, solvents, lawn care products and chemicals, drinking glasses, dishes,
mirrors or window glass, light bulbs, broken glass, cans used for chemicals or
paint, appliances, tools, batteries, hangers, aerosol spray cans, books, phone
books, paper products containing food products (example: pizza boxes).  (Ord.
40-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   919.04  BULKY WASTE DEFINED
   "Bulky Waste", for the purpose of municipal collection will include: 
stoves, refrigerators, water tanks, washing machines, furniture, railroad ties
(2 per week), tires (2 per week off the rim), ladders, Christmas trees, lawn
mowers, television sets, sinks, and similar items.  (Ord. 40- 2013.  Passed 4-
9-13.)
   919.05  COLLECTION LIMITED.
   The City collection shall be limited to the accumulation of Refuse/
Recyclables in all single and two-family residences within the corporate
limits. In addition, such collection shall be available to unit owners of
condominium properties when:
   (a)   The fee to the single unit stands in the name of an individual owner;
   (b)   The owner pays general real estate tax upon the unit;
   (c)   The unit abuts or joins upon a public street right of way and deposit
of rubbish is made to the curb;
   (d)   All other collection practices herein defined are in compliance with
by the unit owners.
   Such collection cannot be offered to apartments, defined and zoned as a
structure to be occupied by three or more families, commercial businesses,
institutions or industries. In the event a residence is located on a parcel of
land with another such use, only the normal residential collection herein
authorized shall be made, except as provision has been made herein for
condominiums.  (Ord. 40-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   919.06  PRECOLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)    Refuse.  All rubbish shall be drained of liquids and food products
placed in a sealable plastic bag and then into an approved container before
being deposited at curb for collection.
   (b)    Trimmings and Clippings. Tree trimmings, hedge clippings and similar
materials shall be cut to length not to exceed four feet,  securely tied in
bundles not more than two feet thick and be no more than 50 lbs. in weight.
   (c)    Flammable or Explosive Materials. Highly flammable, explosive or
hazardous  materials shall not be deposited in containers for collection, but
shall be disposed of as directed by the designated City official  at the
owner's or possessor's expense.
   (d)    Refuse and Recycle Containers.  Containers shall be provided by the
City's contract hauler and shall be maintained in a good state of repair by the
homeowner/tenant. Any container that may have ragged or sharp edges or any
defect which is liable to hamper or injure any person collecting contents
thereof, shall be promptly reported to the City's Public Works Department. 
Containers shall have covers to keep out rain and snow. Residents shall make
every effort to get all items inside the provided containers. However, best
efforts will be made to collect items outside of the containers if properly
prepared.
   (e)     Noncompliance to Pre-collection Practices. Any refuse and
recyclables not complying with these pre-collection practices shall not be
collected. Residents having more refuse and recyclables than herein prescribed
shall make arrangement for the disposal thereof with private haulers.
   (f)     Bulky Waste.  All items shall be placed at the curb along with the
refuse and recyclables to be collected.  Appliance doors shall be removed prior
to placing the items for removal.  All hazardous materials such as oil, fuel
and anti-freeze must be removed from these items. Note: Freon may remain in air
conditioning units and refrigerators.
   (g)    Recyclables.  All recyclables should be rinsed to remove food
residue, lids removed, labels removed, placed in a sealable plastic bag and
placed inside an approved container.  (Ord. 40-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
CHAPTER 921
Commercial and Industrial Refuse and Recyclables Collection
921.01   Definitions.
921.02   License required; number to be issued.
921.03   License fee.
921.04   Application.
921.05   License revocation.
921.06   Collector's uniform; license display.
921.07   Precollection practices.
921.08   Collection practices.
921.09   Depositing of rubbish.
921.10   Collection and disposal fees.
921.11   Hours of  collection.
921.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Vehicle loads dropping, sifting, leaking - see TRAF.
339.08
      Pollution of watercourses - see GEN. OFF.
521.08,
521.09
      Disposal of garbage and rubbish on public and private ways see
         GEN. OFF.
521.10
      Burning rubbish and garbage - see FIRE PREV. Ch.
1503
   921.01  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their deviations shall have the meaning given herein. The word "shall" is
always mandatory and not merely directory.
   (a)   "Hauler" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind licensed to collect rubbish,
refuse and garbage in the Municipality.
   (b)   "Mayor" means the Mayor of the Municipality.
   (c)   "Building Department" means the Building Department of the City of
Twinsburg.
   (d)   "Building Commissioner" means the Building Commissioner of the City of
Twinsburg.
   (e)   "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (f)    "Refuse" means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid wastes
(except body wastes), including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleanings, dead
animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes.
   (g)   "Recyclables" means those materials that can be collected and
processed into new products.  Recyclable materials include but are not limited
to:  glass, paper, metal, plastic, textiles, electronics, oils, anti-freeze
fluid, and cardboard.
   (h)   "Rubbish" or "Garbage" means all rejected waste matter accumulating in
City buildings, public and private schools, charitable institutions, dwelling
houses, stores, hotels or other places of habitation and business in the City
and which shall include such matter as rags, excelsior, straw, pasteboard
boxes, old clothes, shoes, rubber and other scraps, burlap, discarded
mattresses, carpets, matting, oil cloth, junk, scrap metals, broken glass,
crockery, enameled ware, tin cans, cooking utensils, hardware, etc.
   (i)   "City" or "Municipality" means the Municipality of Twinsburg, Ohio.
      (Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.02  LICENSE REQUIRED; NUMBER TO BE ISSUED.
   (a)   No person shall engage in the business of hauling household rubbish,
refuse, garbage or recyclables within the corporate limits unless he/she shall
first obtain a license therefore in the form provided by the City of Twinsburg
Building Department nor shall he/she haul from commercial, industrial,
mercantile or office structures without first obtaining a permit therefore.
   (b)   The number of commercial and industrial haulers authorized to do
business within the corporate limits shall not be limited, so long as they
comply with all regulatory, licensing and income tax requirements of this City.
Commercial and industrial haulers are defined as those persons, firms and
corporations serving business establishments located within the various
commercial and industrial zoning classifications within the City, or those
nonconforming commercial and industrial uses located within the corporate
limits. Nothing herein, however, shall prohibit any commercial business or
industry from operating its own on-site disposal system.  (Ord. 41-2013. 
Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.03  LICENSE FEE.
   The City of Twinsburg Building Department shall collect a fee of fifty
dollars ($50.00) for each domestic license or commercial permit issued under
the provisions of Section
921.02, which fee shall be for the calendar year for which the license is
issued. No more than one license shall be required of each hauler regardless of
the number of vehicles authorized to do business in this Municipality.  (Ord.
41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.04  APPLICATION.
   City of Twinsburg Building Commissioner shall review each application for
residential hauler and commercial, industrial, mercantile and office building
haulers to determine the suitability of such applicant to render the services
of a hauler. The applicant shall furnish and file with the City the following:
   (a)   The name, photograph and personal history statement of all persons to
be engaged in the collection of refuse in the Municipality;
   (b)   A policy of liability insurance issued for the life of the license or
permit applied for or longer, by a responsible insurance company, approved as
to sufficiency by the Building Commissioner and as to legality by the Director
of Law, providing indemnity for or protection to the applicant against loss
resulting from the operation of each vehicle to the extent of one million 
dollars ($1,000,000) on account of injury or death of one person in any one
accident; two million  dollars ($2,000,000) on account of injury or death of
more than one person in any one accident; and no less than five hundred 
thousand dollars ($500,000) for property damage.
   (c)   A list of trucks to be engaged in such business within the
Municipality to include make, model, tonnage, serial number, capacity, etc.
   (d)   Proof that such vehicle(s) have been inspected by a police department,
garage or similar agency and that all vehicles and equipment are in operable
and safe condition.  (Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.05  LICENSE REVOCATION.
   The license or permit required by Section
921.02 may be revoked by the Building Commissioner if the holder thereof
violates any of the provisions or regulations of this chapter.
(Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.06  COLLECTOR'S UNIFORM; LICENSE DISPLAY.
   (a)   Each employee of a licensed or permitted hauler while engaged in the
collection of refuse in the Municipality shall wear a uniform which shall
display the name of the licensed or permitted hauler.
   (b)   Each truck used in the collection of refuse shall display the name of
the licensed or permitted hauler. 
(Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.07  PRECOLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)    Separation of Refuse.  Garbage, ashes and rubbish shall each be
placed and maintained in separate containers.
   (b)   Refuse Containers.  Duty to provide and maintain in sanitary
condition. Refuse containers shall be maintained in good condition. Any
container that does not conform to the provisions of this chapter, or that may
have ragged or sharp edges or any other defect liable to hamper or injure the
person collecting the contents thereof shall be promptly replaced upon notice.
The hauler shall have the authority to refuse collection services for failure
to comply herewith.
   
   (c)     Storing of Refuse.
      (1)   Public places. No person shall place any refuse in any street,
alley or other public place, or upon any private property whether owned by such
person or not within the Municipality unless it is in proper containers for
collection or under express approval granted by the Building Commissioner. No
person shall throw or deposit any refuse in any stream or other body of water.
      (2)   Unauthorized accumulation. Any unauthorized accumulation of refuse
on any premises is declared to be a nuisance and is prohibited. Failure to
remove any existing accumulation of refuse within thirty days after the
effective date of this chapter shall be deemed a violation of this chapter.
      (3)   Scattering of refuse. No person shall cast, place, sweep or deposit
anywhere within the Municipality any refuse in such a manner that it may he
carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, alley, sewer,
parkway or other public place or into any occupied premises within the
Municipality.
         (Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.08  COLLECTION PRACTICES.
   (a)    Special Refuse Problems.
      (1)    Contagious disease refuse.  The removal of wearing, bedding or
other refuse from homes or other places where highly infectious or contagious
diseases have prevailed should be performed under the supervision and direction
of the Summit County Health Department. Such refuse shall not be placed in
containers for regular, collections.
      (2)    Flammable or explosive refuse. Highly flammable or explosive
materials shall not be placed in containers for regular collection but shall be
disposed of as directed by the Building Commissioner at the expense of the
owner or possessor thereof.
   (b)   Requirements for Vehicles.  All haulers shall use a watertight vehicle
provided with a tight cover and so operated as to prevent offensive odors
escaping therefrom and refuse from being thrown, dropped or spilled.
      (1)   All Commercial and Industrial facilities shall maintain regular
collection and hauling of garbage, refuse and recyclables. Hauling schedules
shall be established and maintained in order to prevent overflowing of
containers, nuisance odors and vector attraction.
      (2)   Although recycling of useful materials is not a requirement of this
chapter it is recommended and encouraged by the City of Twinsburg through its
"Green Initiative".  The recycling of materials for processing into new
products reduces the consumption of raw materials, reduces energy use, reduces
air and water pollution, lowers greenhouse gas emissions and minimizes the need
for conventional waste disposal in landfills.
   
   (c)   Requirements for Placing Refuse Containers.  No person shall place or
permit any refuse container to remain between the building setback line and the
street before 12:00 noon on the day prior to the scheduled refuse collection
date and after 7:00 p. m. on the day of the collection.  (Ord. 41-2013.  Passed
4-9-13.)
   921.09  DEPOSITING OF RUBBISH.
   No rubbish shall be deposited by the holder of a hauler's license or permit
within the corporate limits except at a place designated in writing by the
Mayor.
(Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.10  COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL FEES.
   The fees to be charged by duly licensed haulers of garbage and refuse
hereunder shall be as established between the licensed hauler and the customer
under precept of democratic, free-enterprise business initiative provided
however that:
   (a)   Council reserves the right to regulate such maximum fees in the future
should competitive, free enterprise prove not to be beneficial to residents,
and
   (b)   Council requires duly licensed haulers to assess the same going fee to
persons similarly situated within the Municipality so as not to engage in any
discriminatory practices that are not related to the variable factors of time
of employees expended, volume of garbage or trash to be hauled, distance to be
hauled from structure, nature of garbage and/or refuse, etc.
      (Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.11  HOURS OF COLLECTION.
   All duly licensed haulers of garbage, rubbish, trash and debris hereunder
shall undertake such business upon the public streets and ways of the City only
during the daylight hours between sunrise and sunset in order to preclude such
operations within the corporate limits in the night season.
(Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
   921.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
921.08(e) is guilty of a fourth degree misdemeanor. Whoever violates any other
provision of this chapter is guilty of a minor misdemeanor. Each day during
which a violation of any provision of this Chapter exists shall be considered a
separate offense.
(Ord. 41-2013.  Passed 4-9-13.)
CHAPTER 923
Municipal Cemetery
923.01   Short title.
923.02   Definitions.
923.03   Authority of the Mayor.
923.04   Rules and regulations.
923.05   Superintendent's appointment.
923.06   Superintendent's duties.
923.07   Rules for interment.
923.08   Lot costs and expenses.
923.09   Records of ownership.
923.10   Cemetery accounts.
923.11   Reports.
923.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Cemeteries - see Ohio R.C. Ch. 759
         Burial permits - see Ohio R.C. 3705.24 et seq.
         Violating regulations in cemeteries - see GEN. OFF.
541.08
   923.01  SHORT TITLE .
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Twinsburg Municipal
Cemetery Ordinance."
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.02  DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and
their deviations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent
with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in
the plural number include the singular number, and words in the singular number
include the plural number. The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely
directory.
   (a)    "Municipal Cemetery" and "Cemetery" mean the Municipal Cemetery of
Twinsburg.
   (b)    "Person" means any person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, company or organization of any kind.
   (c)    "Superintendent" means the Superintendent of the Municipal Cemetery.
   (d)    "City" means the Municipality of Twinsburg, Ohio.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.03  AUTHORITY OF THE MAYOR.
   The Mayor shall manage, operate and maintain the Municipal Cemetery subject
to any limitations and restrictions set forth herein or contained in any
applicable law.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.04  RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Mayor shall establish rules and regulations for the use of the Cemetery
relating to:
   (a)    Subdividing the cemetery into lots.
   (b)    Capacity of each lot.
   (c)    Location of graves.
   (d)    Type of plantings, monuments and markers that will be permitted for
the proper and most attractive development of the Cemetery.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.05  SUPERINTENDENT'S APPOINTMENT.
   The Mayor may appoint a Superintendent of the Municipal Cemetery if he
determines that one is necessary. The Superintendent shall not be subject to
Civil Service and shall be subject to removal at any time by the Mayor.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.06  SUPERINTENDENT'S DUTIES.
   (a)    Direct Cemetery. The Superintendent shall look after and take proper
care of the Cemetery and see that no lot therein is used or occupied in
violation of this chapter or of any rule or regulation promulgated by the
Mayor.
   (b)    Collect and Turn Over Fees. All fees and charges collected by the
Superintendent for duties and services performed in connection with the
Cemetery shall be for the use of the Municipality and shall immediately be
turned over by him to the Director of Finance.
   (c)    Supervise Interment. The Superintendent shall cause the graves to be
dug and properly inter the dead when called upon to do so.
   In the event that no Superintendent is appointed, the Mayor shall assume and
carry out the duties of such Superintendent herein required of him.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.07  RULES FOR INTERMENT.
   No deceased person shall be interred in the Cemetery until the
Superintendent has found:
   (a)    That a burial permit has been obtained from the Public Health Office
as required by law;
   (b)    That the lot in which burial is to be made has been fully paid for;
   (c)    That the person arranging for such burial has the right to the use of
such lot;
   (d)    That such lot is not used beyond its capacity;
   (e)    That proper record is made of the name and age of the deceased person
and of the exact location of the grave.
      (Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.08  LOT COSTS AND EXPENSES.
   (a)    The following lot costs and expenses of grave opening and closing are
hereby established:
 
Residents - one grave lot                                              $ 100.00
Residents - four grave lots                                            350.00
Nonresidents - one grave lot                                           200.00
Nonresidents - four grave lots                                         700.00
Opening and closing costs for each grave provided                      100.00
There shall be no Sunday or legal holiday burials except as may be
authorized in unusual hardship cases by the Mayor. Additional cost for   50.00
any Saturday, Sunday or holiday
Exhumation and removal under any circumstances                         250.00
   The Mayor shall record such lot costs of all unsold lots in the Cemetery on
an official map or plan of such Cemetery that shall be kept on file open to
public inspection in the office of the Mayor. There shall be no discrimination
on the sale of lots except as to residents and nonresidents.
   (b)    Any person desiring to purchase a particular lot or lots, for the
purpose for which it is intended, shall be permitted to do so upon payment of
the price fixed for such lot or upon making arrangements according to rules and
regulations that may be established by the Mayor, for the purchase of such lot
on an installment plan.
   (c)    Any person wishing to re-tender a deed back to the City may do so and
be reimbursed the same cost that was originally paid for the lot by his
predecessor in title. There shall be no obligation, however, on the part of the
City to accept such re-tender of title unless the same is deemed advisable by
the Mayor. Persons wishing to effect a private transfer of ownership upon City
records may do so at the cost of ten dollars ($10.00) per deed.
(Ord. 50-1973. Passed 5-22-73.)
   923.09  RECORDS OF OWNERSHIP.
   The Mayor shall cause a full and complete record to be kept of the ownership
of all lots in the Cemetery, of the burial capacity of each lot sold and
unsold, of the location of each grave, of the names of the persons buried in
each grave that has been or shall hereafter be used and of the date of burial
of each.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.10  CEMETERY ACCOUNTS.
   The Mayor shall cause to be kept full and detailed accounts of the receipts
and expenditures on account of the Cemetery, and shall turn over to the
Director of Finance all moneys collected on such account.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.11  REPORTS.
   The Mayor shall make an annual report on the condition of the Cemetery to
Council with all information necessary to recommending the amount that should
be appropriated for the Cemetery in the budget.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
   923.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more than
two hundred dollars ($200.00). Each day such violation is committed or
permitted to continue shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 36-1961. Passed 5-9-61.)
CHAPTER 925
Park and Recreation Regulations
   EDITOR’S NOTE:  The Rules and Regulations of the Municipal Swimming Pool are
on file in the Mayor’s office, with the Recreation Board and at the Municipal
Swimming Pool.
925.01   Definitions.
925.02   Parks and recreation fees.
925.03   Use of Municipal facilities.
925.04   Specialized program fees.
925.05   Guidelines for determining the amount to be charged.
925.06   Refunds.
CROSS REFERENCES
      Land appropriation for parks - see Ohio R.C. 715.21, 719.01
      Authority to establish and maintain a municipal swimming pool - see Ohio
R.C. 717.01, 755.12
      Playgrounds - see Ohio R.C. 755.12 et seq.
      Power to regulate vehicle speed in parks - see Ohio R.C. 4511.07(E)
      Department of Parks and Recreation - see ADM. Ch.
135
   925.01  DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, “resident” means an inhabitant of the City when an
activity is fully conducted upon City owned property.  “Nonresident” means all
other persons participating in such activity.
   The word “resident”, when the activity is conducted upon township property,
school board property or when the facilities of such entities are being used,
means an inhabitant of the City school district and “nonresident” means all
other persons participating in such program.
(Ord. 34-1981.  Passed 4-28-81.)
   925.02  PARKS AND RECREATION FEES.

(Ord. 22-2014.  Passed 3-18-14.)
   925.03  USE OF MUNICIPAL FACILITIES.
   (a)    Other than routine, planned governmental activities, Municipal
buildings, including the Community Center, shall not be made available for use
by any persons or groups, without prior written request to and written consent
from the Mayor, and prior agreement on the part of such interested persons or
groups to hold the City harmless from all liabilities and to compensate the
City for all reasonable additional costs and expenses incurred by the City as a
result of such activities. In addition, such persons or groups shall be
required to advance a security deposit of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each
day of use desired, to a maximum of three hundred dollars ($300.00), from which
deposit deductions may be made for any expenses or extraordinary damages
arising from such activities. The proposed use of such buildings by such
individuals or groups shall be uses that are open to the public and related to
general municipal activities and interests.
   (b)    The persons and groups referred to herein are City residents and
City-based groups.
   (c)    In the exercise of his discretion, the Mayor may waive the foregoing
requirements as to certain organizations, for example, the Boy Scouts of
America.
(Ord. 25-1984. Passed 3-13-84.)
   925.04  SPECIALIZED PROGRAM FEES.
   The Parks and Recreation Director, with approval of the Mayor, is hereby
granted permission to establish specialized program fees to offset the costs
incurred in operating parks and recreation services and facilities when fees
are determined appropriate because of one or more of the following:
   (a)    Cost per user hour of the service or the facility is high. This may
be so where:
      (1)    The service uses consumable material;
      (2)    The service requires a facility with high capital, operating or
maintenance costs;
      (3)    The service requires special preparation or clean-up;
      (4)    The service requires special instruction at extra cost.
   (b)    To expand activities at the least possible cost in the providing of
activities of a special interest nature that extend the program beyond the
normal operation.
   (c)    Use of the service or facility tends to be limited to a relatively
few individuals or special interest groups of a private character.
   (d)    Public property is used for private economic gain, therefore, the
fees charged for use of public recreation facilities by private and closed
membership groups shall be comparable to commercial rates.
   (e)    Admission to special events where profits are used to extend the
activity or cover the cost of the event.
   (f)    When a service is enjoyed by a considerable number of nonresidents
who have not supported the service through taxation.
      (Ord. 34-1981. Passed 4-28-81.)
   925.05  GUIDELINES FOR DETERMINING THE AMOUNT TO BE CHARGED.
   The following factors shall be considered when determining special program
fees.
   (a)    The fee may be determined on the basis of actual cost of rendering
the service, including the interest and amortization of the investment.
   (b)    The fee may be computed on the basis of direct operating expenses,
disregarding capital improvement items.
   (c)    The fee may be computed at the rate which will result in efficient
use of a given area or improvement.
   (d)    Whenever possible, special or reduced rates should be established to
accommodate low-income or elderly citizens.
(Ord. 34-1981. Passed 4-28-81.)
   925.06  REFUNDS.
   The Parks and Recreation Department is hereby granted and delegated the
authority to adopt a system of refunds for any cancelled programs or unusual
circumstances when a participant must withdraw.
(Ord. 34-1981. Passed 4-28-81.)
CHAPTER 927
Municipal Snow Removal Services
927.01   Snow removal limitations.
927.02   Applications.
927.03   Falsification of information.
927.04   Emergency snow removal contractors.
927.99   Penalty.
CROSS REFERENCES
         Placing obstructions in streets - see TRAF.
311.01
         Vehicles using spikes, lugs and chains - see
            TRAF.
339.10
   927.01  SNOW REMOVAL LIMITATIONS.
   (a)    The Parks and Recreation Department is authorized to provide, by
order of the Mayor, snow removal service for the following residents:
      (1)   Persons over the age of sixty-five years, provided no able-bodied
person under sixty-five years of age resides at the same address and that such
service is not provided by any homeowners' association;
      (2)    Persons physically or mentally handicapped who receive annually
net income of less than fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) provided no able-
bodied person under sixty-five years of age resides at the same address and
that such service is not provided by any homeowners' association.
   Notwithstanding the foregoing requirements, the Mayor may, within his or her
discretion, authorize temporary snow removal services in extreme or emergency
situations.
   (b)    No snow plowing will be furnished to those qualified residents except
when the accumulation of snow reaches approximately three inches. Driveways
shall not be cleared more than once in a twenty-four hour period and only after
all City streets have been cleared to the satisfaction of the Director of
Public Services.
   (c)    The City snow removal vehicles will clear no more than a single
driveway width. The applicant shall indicate the location of the driveway
through the use of driveway markers, which shall be visible from the cab of
snow plow vehicles. Applicants shall not have side or overhead driveway
obstructions which may interfere with snow removal operations.
(Ord. 61-2017.  Passed 6-13-17.)
   927.02  APPLICATIONS.
   (a)    City residents who qualify for City snow plowing and who desire
plowing services must obtain and complete an Application and Income
Verification Form as provided by the City.
   (b)    Upon completion, the application, income verification form, a
doctor's letter evidencing physical or mental handicap disability, if
applicable and necessary, and a signed release of the City from liability for
any damages incurred during snow plow activity shall be returned by mail or in
person to the Community Center/Senior Center no later than the last business
day of November of each year. 
   (c)   In addition to the foregoing, no application will be processed without
the submission of an application fee. The amount of the application fee shall
be determined as follows:
 
Household Annual Income       Fee
Less than $32,000.00          No Fee
From $32,000.00 to $60,000.00 $75.00*
Excess of $60,000.00          Not Eligible
   *Any eligible resident that submits a completed application on or before the
last business day of November shall receive a $25.00 discount.
(Ord. 61-2017.  Passed 6-13-17.)
   927.03  FALSIFICATION OF INFORMATION.
   The falsification of any information contained in a snow plowing service
application, or an accompanying medical letter, of a City resident shall result
in immediate and permanent ineligibility for snow plowing services by the
Department of Public Services and the applicant shall reimburse the City within
sixty days of costs incurred during such snow removal at a rate determined by
the Director of Public Services.
(Ord. 106-1986. Passed 11-18-86.)
   927.04  EMERGENCY SNOW REMOVAL CONTRACTORS.
   (a)   The Director of Public Services is authorized to employ private snow
removal contractors to assist the City in rendering the services set forth in
Section
927.01 when he has determined that an emergency exists and that there are
inadequate City personnel to perform the services set forth therein.
   (b)    The Director shall obtain such private snow removal contractors after
ascertaining, by means of informal bid, the cost of removal to be charged by
individual contractors and shall make arrangements and contracts with the
selected contractors in advance of each winter season to be assured of their
availability on an on-call basis during the ensuing winter months upon such
terms and specifications as he shall prepare.
   (c)    Payment for such private contracting services shall be made by the
Director or Deputy Director of Finance from funds appropriated to such purpose,
which appropriation is hereby authorized.
(Ord. 106-1986. Passed 11-18-86.)
   927.99  PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter is guilty of a misdemeanor of the first degree subject to a fine of not
more than one thousand dollars ($1,000), or imprisonment of not more than six
months, or both. Each instance of violation or failure to comply shall
constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 106-1986. Passed 11-18-86.)
CHAPTER 929
